Useful information. In life there are only 2 problems--mind and the body. To feel better reduce negative thoughts. Be careful what you feed your mind.  Avoid comparing yourself with others, reduce negative social media and avoid constipation as it affects the mind. Increase the serotining levels in the brain. Your breathing is closely related to the brain [mind] and gives relief from stress-anxiety.  For a relaxed mind observe the sensations of your incoming--outgoing breath at the entrance of the nostrils  for  10-15-20 minutes or more. You can sit or lie down, neck straight and eyes closed.  Never meditate with expectations but with awareness. Don’t fight your thoughts. With practice the mind will relax.  Keep a reminder to observe your breath sensations throughout the day and night --before sleep, when reading, at work,  when sitting in the park etc. –anywhere-anytime.   Like me, make this a lifetime habit to have a better life. Best wishes--Counsellor.

cause they have a pool. i woke up in the middle of the night, 2-3am. i didn’t see my mom anywhere so i tried facetiming her on an ipad. no response. she picked up an audio call tho. i asked where she was at. she said she was downstairs “getting breakfast”. i was like it’s 2am, why are you getting breakfast? she said there’s a really long line for food. i believed her. that happened when i was 7 In my experience, depression always comes from external factors (read: people that might be toxic for you). When your mind and body are disturbed, when someone is not supporting you in actually what is good for you, when your safety feeling is disturbed, when you start overthinking and don't see how you can make something work under certain conditions. When your freedom is taken. Then stress and pressure come in. And most importantly, your brain changes it's physical shape and it's hard to regenerate it if you don't do anything about it. How to get out? CHANGE something. Say NO to someone, to something. Book a trip in nature, turn off everything. Rest your feelings and thoughts. We operate the most efficient when we actually think little!

Depression is a lie perpetuated by the healthcare industry for the sole purpose of profit

Saying your depressed is different than the lie categorizing it as Depression. The two are
different. The former statement only acknowledges a symptom that is correctable through
analysis of the cause, addressing the cause and wiping away the feeling of being depressed.
The later creates a condition out of it to perpetuate a pseudo-diagnosis and subsequently
profit through the ongoing medical management of the patient condition by the medical
industry and the dispensation of prescription drugs as maintenance versus cure.

Mainstream medicine deals with the diagnosis of Depression through suppression. It has
little to do with addressing the cause or causes of the condition.
Things that cause depression are events that are seemingly unresolveable, such as the recent
loss of a loved one, loss of employment, loss of a partner or spouse, loss of financial
resources, money...etc. All of the aforementioned events have to do with Loss. Depression
is a relatively new diagnosis. So HOW did previous generations deal with a funda"mental"
event like this? They addressed the cause...they "Dealt" with the cause, something the weak
snowflake generation of the current "me me me" generation avoids...working through their
problems methodically.
Some of the aforementioned events require a healthy emotional and painful journey to
completion. It is the pain within this journey that the snowflakes of this generation are
avoiding, and they do so, temporarily, with the benevolence of the psuedo-healthcare
industry who prescribe chemical crutches (for profit), to "help". This only masks the pain
and interrupts the necessary journey to completion and depression elimination. Enter
Self-Pity....the enabler and "Validator"of the condition with the support of the poor excuse

IF YOU HAVE EVER had suicidal thoughts, you’re not alone. It’s very common. And if you suffer from depression, you don’t have a mental disease. You are sane and you’re normal, because life is depressing. It’s filled with pain and suffering. As you go through life, your beloved dog dies. So does your sweet grandma. Then you realize that no one survives. We are all going to die and it seems that there’s nothing we can do about it. That’s very depressing.

TWO QUESTIONS
What is the world’s best-selling book of all time? It’s the Bible. Are you familiar with its story of the rich young ruler who ran to Jesus, knelt down and asked, “Good Teacher, what should I do to inherit eternal life?” How would you answer that question? Before you answer, let me give you a quick scenario: Imagine you feel a painful lump under your arm. So you go to the doctor. He examines it, looks concerned, does some tests, and comes back with a grim expression and says, “I’m so sorry to tell you this, but you have lymph node cancer. It has metastasized. You have about two weeks to live. I will give you some medication to help ease the pain. I’m so sorry.”

You go home and lie on your bed. You’re too sick to see anyone or go anywhere. All you can think about is that one question: “What should I do to inherit eternal life?” This isn’t a far-fetched scenario. More than 600,000 Americans will die of cancer in the next twelve months, and over 8.2 million will die of the disease worldwide. Put yourself into that frightening scenario and ask yourself, “What should I do to inherit eternal life?” Do you know the answer?

THE CAUSE OF DEPRESSION
According to the world’s best-selling Book, every human being is held in bondage to a haunting fear of death. The Bible says that what Jesus accomplished on the cross was so that . . . [He] might free all those who through [the haunting] fear of death were held in slavery throughout their lives. (Hebrews 2:15, Amplified Bible)

FEAR’S ANTIDOTE
If you were standing on the edge of a plane 10,000 feet up, thinking about how you are going to jump and hit the ground face-first at 120 mph, you would understandably be terrified. But if I gave you a parachute, the minute you put it on, you will be able to control your fears. If you completely trust that parachute, you will now know that you will land gently at 8 mph, on your feet. Your fear will be in direct proportion to your faith. If you have total faith in the parachute, you will have no fear. Your faith will rid you of fear.

Let’s now apply that analogy to faith in Jesus. When He was asked, “Good Teacher, what shall I do to inherit eternal life?” He replied: “Why do you call Me good? No one is good but One, that is, God. You know the commandments: ‘Do not commit adultery,’ ‘Do not murder,’ ‘Do not steal,’ ‘Do not bear false witness,’ ‘Do not defraud,’ ‘Honor your father and your mother.’ ” (Mark 10:18,19)

Jesus told him that only God is good; only He is morally perfect. Then He gave the man five of the Ten Commandments. This is because we may think that we are good, but the Ten Commandments show us that we’re not. For example, how many lies have you told in your life? Have you ever stolen something (irrespective of its value)? Have you taken God’s name in vain (including “OMG”)? Jesus said that if we look with lust, we commit adultery in the heart (see Matthew 5:27,28). Have you ever looked with lust?

If you answered “Yes” to these questions, you’ve admitted that you are a lying, thieving, blasphemous adulterer at heart. So if God judged you by the Ten Commandments on Judgment Day (we’ve looked at four of them), would you be innocent or guilty? No doubt you (like the rest of us) will be guilty. If you’re guilty on Judgment Day, will you go to Heaven or Hell? If any of us were judged by the Ten Commandments, we would justly end up in Hell. What then should you do to be saved from death and Hell?

Fortunately, there is an answer to the question, “What shall I do to inherit eternal life?” Just over 2,000 years ago, God became a perfect, sinless human being in Jesus of Nazareth. The Bible says: And without controversy great is the mystery of godliness: God was manifested in the flesh . . . (1 Timothy 3:16) And the reason He became a human being was to suffer and die on the cross. When Jesus was on the cross He took the punishment for the sin of the world. We broke God’s Law (the Ten Commandments are called “the moral Law”) and Jesus paid the fine. That’s what happened on the cross. That’s why He cried out, “It is finished!” just before He died. In other words, the debt has been paid.

If you’re in court and someone pays your fine, the judge can legally let you go even though you’re guilty. God can dismiss our case, and legally let us live forever, because Jesus paid our fine on the cross: “For God so loved the world that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him should not perish but have everlasting life” (John 3:16). Then Jesus rose from the dead, defeating death. Today, if you repent and trust in Jesus, God promises to give you eternal life as a free gift.

DEATH IS EVIDENCE
Do you know what “death” is? It’s our wages. The Bible says, “The wages of sin is death” (Romans 6:23). We earn the sentence of death by our sin. It’s like a judge saying to a mass murderer, “You have earned the death penalty.” Death is evidence that God is serious about sin. In His morally perfect eyes, our sin is deadly serious. Today, right now, please confess and forsake your sins and put your trust in Jesus Christ (like you’d trust a parachute). Do that, and God will not only save you from death, but He will save you from the fear of death. Remember the analogy of how fearful it would be to jump 10,000 feet without a parachute? And how, if you were given a parachute, you could control your fears? Put on the Lord Jesus Christ and trust in Him with all of your heart, and you will rid yourself of that haunting fear that causes depression.

Millions of human beings suffer from depression because they live without faith in Jesus. They have no hope in their death. But in Christ, you now have a living hope, both in this life and in your death. You need never fear as long as you trust in Jesus. Look at the promises of Scripture: What then shall we say to these things? If God is for us, who can be against us? He who did not spare His own Son, but delivered Him up for us all, how shall He not with Him also freely give us all things? Who shall bring a charge against God’s elect? It is God who justifies. Who is he who condemns? It is Christ who died, and furthermore is also risen, who is even at the right hand of God, who also makes intercession for us. Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? Shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or sword? As it is written: “For Your sake we are killed all day long; we are accounted as sheep for the slaughter.” Yet in all these things we are more than conquerors through Him who loved us. For I am persuaded that neither death nor life, nor angels nor principalities nor powers, nor things present nor things to come, nor height nor depth, nor any other created thing, shall be able to separate us from the love of God which is in Christ Jesus our Lord. (Romans 8:31–39)

To grow in your faith, make a habit of reading your Bible daily. Without fail. And make sure that you obey what you read. God will never let you down. Depression is the most common illness worldwide and the leading cause of disability. It is different from the fluctuation in the mood that people experience as a part of normal life. Depression causes a feeling of sadness or loss of interest in activities. It can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems and can decrease a person’s ability to function properly

Symptoms include –change in appetite, trouble sleep, thoughts of death, difficulty in concentration, feeling worthless. Also medical conditions, e.g. thyroid problems, a brain tumor or vitamin deficiency can mimic the symptoms of depression.

HELP WITH DEPRESSION (1 of 3)

There are 3 basic principles:  1. Receive support from family and friends who should listen, understand and love the depressed person. 2. Seek professional help (diagnosis and adequate therapy). 3. Understand that depression will improve or heal with time if you are patient, prudent, and determined to fight it. To do this, you have to gradually improve your surrounding environment and personal circumstances on three levels:  A) Physical Level  - Be active and improve your inner well-being.  - Have a healthy diet (Omega 3 ALA, DHA and EPA, proteins, vitamins, few carbohydrates and sugars, Q10, minerals: magnesium, potassium, zinc, iron, good hydration, etc.), anti-inflammatory diet https://youtu.be/Wv9uJZ2gzjQ preferably vegetarian, etc.  -Quantity and quality of sleep, not sleeping too little or too much (7-8 hrs. for most people), go to bed at around the same time and get up at the same time, having dinner at least two hours before going to sleep, etc.  -Receive enough sunlight, schedule daily walks outside, contact with nature, physical exercise, etc.  -Maintain upright body posture, straight back.  -Practice Hatha yoga, Tai chi, Qigong, etc.  See documentaries, video tutorials and books about it.  Level 1 music: rhythmic, virtuosic (ex: Cameron Carpenter, Yamandu Costa, Hilary Hahn, virtuous children, etc.), fun music, joyous soundtracks, for example: "7 Brides for 7 Brothers" https://youtu.be/m2pFtpjuSrs "The Magnificent 7" https://youtu.be/jMTomlNR81A "Mary Poppins" https://youtu.be/kG6O4N3wxf8 https://youtu.be/4M1XC00RMA8 "The Sound of Music" https://youtu.be/4M1XC00RMA8 https://youtu.be/pLm07s8fnzM “Chitty chitty bang bang” https://youtu.be/ZTTzcXSLjhI "Les Demoiselles de Rochefort" https://youtu.be/0S8_x-qOCBI https://youtu.be/FGSNxuBdRw8 "Singing in the Rain" https://youtu.be/D1ZYhVpdXbQ Joyful John Williams Soundtracks (In Search of the Lost Ark, E.T, Star Wars, etc.) E. HELP WITH DEPRESSION (2 of 3)

B) Mental and Emotional Level
-Learn to think and feel correctly. Feel good about your personal achievements. Be grateful for what you have and for any help that you may receive, etc. -Cultivate self-control (study from Dunedin New Zealand University).
Do not continually dramatize, complain, or blame. Do the right thing. Take care of yourself and others. - Eliminate bad habits for mental health: desires, adherence to negative thoughts, vanity, selfishness, etc.

First of all, I've never really opened up to people about it... my wife knows, maybe 2 more people I've met throughout my life, but overall, I'm not a person who talks about things.

I've never been diagnosed, I don't know what it's called... but I would like to finally let it off my chest. Why I despise myself, why I feel ashamed of who I am. I always pretend to be the happy one, joke around, friendly, sarcastic, dark humour... but it's always there, the physical pain in my chest and my brain, and no one knows it. It's not something that I did, but more like what I didn't do.

In front of people, I smile a lot, I laugh, I joke, people think I'm a happy person... and I have a happy side, people just don't know the heavy stone inside of me, weighing on my brain, my chest, I can physically feel it in every moment of my life. Even when I'm happy, it's there.

I've never received treatment, I've made a point for myself to not get diagnosed, and I don't want to flush money on a "professional" who doesn't really have a personal bond with me and just gets paid to listen to me. No, I think I'm too cynical for it.

The reason I've decided to post here is because... I've had it weighing me down, being on my soul, my mind, not letting me sleep, bringing dark thoughts into me, since the age of 14-15... I wanted to die then, but I was like, "Better things will come... keep waiting." Better things did come, I have a wife I love, a child I adore, and I know for a fact I would never harm myself, if only not to upset or traumatise them. Like, self-harm is out of the question. However, the heavy loads is still in me. I feel that I need to post here because... why not? I've never tried it, so why not?

Does it make me weak for opening up? I don't think so. The fact I was passive and did nothing about the entrapment and emasculation I've experienced growing up with a possessive mum who thinks a bear hug of preventing you from living is love and "protection."

I've had a few heavy lows in my life, one at 16-17, one at about 24-25, and one now. Stuff bother me - I can't sleep, I always feel low about myself, I simply hate who I am, that is the truth.

I just really hate myself - like, I look in the mirror, I just feel disgusted. I just don't like who I am), my life in the sense of what I've done with it.

Like, I feel old, finished, like there's nothing left in me - I'm 30. When I go home, if I see high school students going home, or when I run into people in their early 20s... I just feel so old. They're young, enjoying life, have their whole lives ahead of them, have hope... I never experienced being young, that was deprived for me and I was too passive to do something, but now it's too late.

My mum had paranoia and other issues, never got diagnosed... but just figure this out. Until the age of 16, I was forced to call her every time I arrived at school - my school was 10 min from my home. I felt so humiliated doing it! I literally wasn't allowed to meet friends in the evening like any other normal teenager could until the age of 17-18, because in her mind I could be killed, get into drugs, or whatever... basically, I had to lie in my bed, and choke on my own envy of those who do live and sense of worthlessness while I hear laughter and people making memories, being young from outside my window.

In her sick, selfish mind that was love. I did nothing.

I finally started going out with friends at the age of 17... not that my mum liked it, every time I went out she had a panic attack, pretended to faint on the floor, called me a million times... I didn't answer, but you can imagine that whenever I came home she was there in the flat, with a slapped-arse face acting like I actually did something bad to her.

In her mind, I was being selfish - not her after trapping me and preventing me from leaving, she claimed I was being selfish for daring to go out with friends and "not thinking about her."

It affected my personality. Even though I met friends and they all thought I was friendly and fun, I could never form meaningful relationships, I was very introverted, I still kept a distance a lot. I was there for others, but never let anyone get inside my head, inside what I felt.

I was also passive, in a way. I never initiated friendships, it was people doing it to me - this passiveness, both in resisting my mum before the age of 17, and this, are a big part of why I feel ashamed of who I am.

I remember when I was younger, in my early 20s... I still had things to feel good about. Like, when I was 22, people found it impressive I had an MA... people found my knowledge of music and history impressive, the fact I played guitar... thing is, most of those things were a result of me just being stuck at home and not being able to do anything else. I love music, it's my life and I'd never give it up for anything, but nothing else developed within me.

But now... there's nothing. If you're 22 with an MA and knowledge in history it's WOW, if you're 30... like, so?

I never got to experience being young and free, young and happy... and now I'm just fat, 30, ugly... complete nobody.

Thing is, I'd be OK with who I am if I had experienced being young, the joys and disappointments of that time, the life, but I didn't. It's like I've been born old, with no memories of youth to give me something to think about.

Imagine being born old and not having any joyous memories of the past, never being young... that's how I feel.

I'm stuck in this skin, I'm stuck in who I am... and I really hate the person I am. I'm ashamed I was so passive when my mum locked me in the flat, I'm ashamed I remained there until the age of 22 and didn't run away from home, I'm ashamed I always went with the flow and didn't work to approach people, to be the one to initiate friendships, that I was telling myself, "Good things will come"... without realising that you must go towards those things, you must work for them, you can't just expect them to come.

Literally the only thing that I have is to make sure my daughter has a full, fun, and free life. To have the happy upbringing I didn't have, to be outgoing and happy. Thing is, you still want to have something in you, going for you, and I don't.

Ironically, my mum is actually a good grandmother - thing is, she knows she couldn't get away with the sh** she did now.

But when she dies, I know for a fact I'll be zero upset. I'll be upset for my daughter being upset, but I have zero sympathy of love for my mum.

At one point, I wrote to her and tried explaining what she did... she thinks I'm being childish and selfish. According to her, I was spoilt with "too much love" - that abuse is love in her mind.

It's funny, but she thinks I was a spoilt child... my parents never took me to a restaurant (except McDonald's a few times), maybe took me on one holiday, and always made it clear we were too poor for the most basic things that other kids in my school who were much worst off still did, but apparently that's being "spoilt." Thing is, that never bothered me - it was mostly a result of my dad being bitter in general and imposing his "sour grapes" mentality on the whole family.

I'm not asking for a virtual hug or support... it is what it is, nothing can be done, but I felt like I needed to let it out somewhere.

Depression is a widespread condition, affecting millions of people, Christians and non-Christians alike. Those suffering from depression can experience intense feelings of sadness, anger, hopelessness, fatigue, and a variety of other symptoms. They may begin to feel useless and even suicidal, losing interest in things and people that they once enjoyed. Depression is often triggered by life circumstances, such as a loss of job, death of a loved one, divorce, or psychological problems such as abuse or low self-esteem.

The Bible tells us to be filled with joy and praise (Philippians 4:4; Romans 15:11), so God apparently intends for us all to live joyful lives. This is not easy for someone suffering from situational depression, but it can be remedied through God’s gifts of prayer, Bible study and application, support groups, fellowship among believers, confession, forgiveness, and counseling. We must make the conscious effort to not be absorbed in ourselves, but to turn our efforts outward. Feelings of depression can often be solved when those suffering with depression move the focus from themselves to Christ and others.

Clinical depression is a physical condition that must be diagnosed by a physician. It may not be caused by unfortunate life circumstances, nor can the symptoms be alleviated by one’s own will. Contrary to what some in the Christian community believe, clinical depression is not always caused by sin. Depression can sometimes be caused by a physical disorder that needs to be treated with medication and/or counseling. Of course, God is able to cure any disease or disorder. However, in some cases, seeing a doctor for depression is no different than seeing a doctor for an injury.

There are some things that those who suffer from depression can do to alleviate their anxiety. They should make sure that they are staying in the Word, even when they do not feel like it. Emotions can lead us astray, but God’s Word stands firm and unchanging. We must maintain strong faith in God and hold even more tightly to Him when we undergo trials and temptations. The Bible tells us that God will never allow temptations into our lives that are too much for us to handle (1 Corinthians 10:13). Although being depressed is not a sin, one is still accountable for the response to the affliction, including getting the professional help that is needed. “Through Jesus, therefore, let us continually offer to God a sacrifice of praise—the fruit of lips that confess his name” (Hebrews 13:15).

Gian Giorgio Trissino
Both I and J were used interchangeably by scribes to express the sound of both the vowel and the consonant. It wasn't until 1524 when Gian Giorgio Trissino, an Italian Renaissance grammarian known as the father of the letter J, made a clear distinction between the two sounds.

There is absolutely no evidence that SSRIs are antidepressants that treat depression, nor that depression is an illness in any way. This video is a joke. Long-term use of these drugs makes depression chronic and more severe. Taking these drugs leads to depression even if you are not depressed to begin with. Interrupting depression with brute chemical force is irresponsible to say the least. SSRIs also increase the number of suicides overall, they do not prevent them. There is no evidence that bipolar disorder is a distinct medical condition or that it is genetic in nature. The true causes of depression are well known, namely trauma and unmet needs over a long period of time. Sometimes traumatic brain injuries will cause depression due to damage to specific white matter tracts. The infantalizing nature of this video is both irritating and predictable.

Read this : This helped me get out of depression. Hopefully it helps you
too. I found it on some website but i forgot what it was. I copied it
and pasted it in my notepad. Now pasting it here:



depression: This is a sensitive topic and here is my take on it.
When you are depressed you feel sad,lonely,bad and you feel like you
just want to end it. See, before you self harm yourself, think about
this: You were a winner. You are a winner. You are still breathing. Just
take a deep breath and think about your childhood when you had no
worries, You had the freedom to dream and think whatever you wanted. No
one said nothing. But, now that very own society is trying to destroy
you. The people are never satisfied. They get jealous and they want you
to do more,cry more. So you have two options: You can either give up and
end this and remain as a loser in the very own cruel society or you can
let go of it and be a winner and create a beautiful life for yourself.
You can watch some cute videos,talk to some people online, share your
worry online and you might find a solution for your problems. If you
don’t find an answer, keep on searching, but don’t give up. Whenever you
get a bad thought in your mind, replace it with two or more positive
thoughts. Imagine a good future, not a bad one. Rewire your brain to
think positively. But remember, IF YOU DON’T FIND AN ANSWER, KEEP ON
SEARCHING. After all there is a solution to every problem and when you
have a will to
live a good life there will be a *way*. PRAY daily, Ask GOD for
forgiveness for your sins and ask him to help you after all he has plans
to give us hope and not leave us. Deuteronomy 31:6" Be strong and
courageous. Do not fear or be in dread of them, for it is the Lord your
God who goes with you. He will not leave you or forsake you."
If you feel like no one loves you or cares for you, You are wrong, God
still loves you midst of all the bad things you have done. So be
thankful to him, pray to him and most importantly believe in him. GO TO A
CHURCH OR A PEACEFUL PLACE AND FILL YOURSELF WITH POSITIVITY. DO GOOD
DEEDS. BE THANKFUL FOR YOUR LIFE AFTER ALL the probability of you being
born was 1:4 trillion. SO we are born a winner. So win over depression. F
it.

There was this girl that I really liked, and I’m pretty sure she liked me too, but every time she would come over and try to talk to me I would just try to distance myself from her for some reason. I have a single mom, and I haven’t seen my dad in a few years. I can have a lot of acquaintances in school, but after that I just spend all my time at home, in my bed by myself. So I really don’t have any friends. And the people that I very rarely do see are mean and usually encourage me to kill myself when I tell them I’m sad, I still only talk to them because I don’t want to be all alone. For anyone depressed, try smiling. It sounds kinda dumb, but when you smile, the muscles in your face sends a message to your brain to become activated, this activation causes chemicals to be released in which many  hormones are released, causing better mood. When you put on a serious face all the time, the muscles are never activated, thus the boost of chemical activation never occurs. Smile, relax and chill. Remember something, sitting and being upset over whatever it is, is never gonna help. Do something about it. Be happy. Smile.

The best tip I can give to people who are depressed is to learn to deal with themselves and learn to do things in their own way and at their own pace. I felt depressed for years and I cried a lot, I went to several psychologists until I could understand. No one will "take your hand and save you" there is no magic solution that will fall on your lap. Learn to accept and take life lighter. Do not compare yourself to others all the time, learn that the world is what it is. Do not try to look at reality based on the filter of your dreams. Strive and move away from the things that pull you down. I'm not saying it's easy, but only you can do it! Keep fighting. Not for your parents or others. Fight for you! Because you deserve it. I'm sure a path will open for you.

I would like to share this comment with everyone who is suffering... Please listen! Anxiety & Depression are caused by the lack of awareness of the voice in your head. Let me explain.. everybody who can speak a fluent language is unconsciously being tormented by the non stop tyrant of self talk and that voice in your head. Just by being aware of this simple truth can already help you shift to your true self. You need to bring presence into your life..let me explain further. By being present I mean be the watcher of the voice in your head! People believe that they have control over their thoughts well my friends unfortunately you don’t! Digestion happens to you, your heart beating happens to you, your body regulating its temperature happens to and unfortunately THINKING HAPPENS TO YOU! it’s involuntary and unfortunately mostly negative. You are a slave to your own unconscious negative thoughts patterns. Just by this simple truth and by bringing awareness to this you are already healing and on the right path to your true self. This too shall pass! One love ❤️

Depression is like drowning when everyone around you is enjoying the swim. It takes a lot of effort to beat it, however, I’ve found through my many years of experience that natural solutions can be really helpful. Most times even better than prescription medication. For those of you having difficulties with depression, I highly recommend the Destroy Depression system. Written by James Gordon, a major depression sufferer who struggled with his own depression for 2 decades, it teaches 7 natural steps that he implemented to heal himself. I have a great deal of empathy for people who are existing in that place right now, because I’ve been caught in that web. The fascinating thing about the web is that you’re the spider in the web of depression, you’re the thing that comes clambering down the web and devours itself, that’s you! What’s really awesome about the state of depression, is that it’s kind of a gateway and the gate-keeper is yourself. And the gate-keeper is asking you this incredible riddle at every moment which is “why live?”. And if you can answer that riddle, then the gate will swing open and you will be allowed out of this awful net and into the party that is modern life. - Duncan Trussell

Yo so I met this girl about 7 months ago. When I first saw her it felt like everything around her exploded, she was just too fine. I approached her and we took off from there. Texting and chatting all that cute shit. After a good 2 weeks she told me she had bipolar depression. I really had no clue on what the depression part was. I had always heard people say "oh this person is bipolar" or when someone would suddenly act up and change emotion people would be like "chill out you bipolar". So when she told me that I asked her what it was. Once she gave me a little piece of information on it I knew not to ask too much questions about it. At that point I had already started caring about her. She's a real beautiful person and I am really grateful she's entered my life. I've researched so much about bipolar depression so I could understand her. Fast forward to now, we're a loving couple but god damn is it a rollercoaster of emotions. I've learned not to take things personal when she gets low. She kinda pushes me away, and at the beginning I thought it was because she didn't care about me. I love her to death and would endure anything for her. She sometimes thinks I'm too good for her and that she doesn't deserve me when she's feeling low. Or she gets tired of life and does a lot of crying. I swear she deserves everything good in this world, like I'm the one that feels like I don't deserve her. I don't think I'll ever stop loving her. I know she loves me a lot also. So I feel like it's my mission to love her when others won't. Even if we do fall apart. Idk that's just a piece of my love story that I thought I'd share. I'm currently high af atm so I'm just kinda reminiscing. I feel for those of you that are suffering from depression especially those with bipolar. You people are real talented. Surround yourselves with good people. Never give up hope and never believe that you're alone. I truly do hope you all see better days. ✌

I don't know how much this can help anyone, if it even will at all, but I have some actual advice that isn't vague or hard to follow (hopefully) for people who do constantly feel worthless and sad all the time. First of all, I've had depression and suicidal thoughts before, where it got so bad that I did physical harm to myself more than once, and I know what it feels like to feel that worthless and pitiful and meaningless.
One thing that always really helped me was to find things that made me laugh. I mean really laugh. Crying-weak-at-the-knees, doubled over and gasping for air laughing. Comedians usually did the trick, and always made me feel so much better. Another was finding other things to focus on, like stories and books and shows. I'm not saying you should constantly be hiding from reality, but you should definitely have a place to escape to and forget about your worries when you need to. Also, getting up and forcing yourself to do little things like fold laundry or do dishes while listening to music, and not having to think and get the satisfsction or getting something done is really great- and if you don't have the energy for that, just close your eyes and listen to some rain or just sleep. Eventually you'll have the energy to hoist yourself up and do something, and all you need is one first step. Another thing, and this is much more based on your beliefs on God and whether or not there's a purpose to everything, is something I've heard been called optimistic nihilism, but it's so much more. The idea is that you're going to die. Yes, you, reading this. You are going to die. Maybe not right now, maybe not in a fes days, maybe not for a couple of decades, but you ARE going to die, and sooner than you think. So will your loved ones, your idols, your ideas, your dreams, your creations, all humans, the solar system and the universe will eventually end.
Okay, but how is that inspirational? Short answer- it's not. But the thing is, all of that is going to happen REGARDLESS, so tell yourself, "what the hell? None of it matters anyway," and go try to find something new to do. Even if it's just go for a walk or go out to meet someone new, you are going to die anyway, so you might as well enjoy your life while it's here. Just go and put yourself out there because, in the end, nothing really matters anyways.

I love the book Nutrient Power by Dr William Walsh. Life changing!!!! This man has dedicated his life to study patterns of people with mental illness and has the worlds largest database that he uses for his own scientific research. He will tell you what mainstream medicine will not. He believes that depression falls into 5 phenotypes.
We all need to read it and get our blood and urine tested for our own biochemical needs to see if we fit into a particular phenotype. Maybe you've wondered why a particular medicine that worked so well for someone else, doesn't work for you?
Even simple Nutrients can make conditions better or worse. For instance a person who is under methylated will exhibit depression and anxiety and is intolerant to folic acid and thus supplementing will make that person worse. Unfortunately a lot of our food is fortified with this supplement. At the same time another phenotype of depression is folic acid deficiency! This explains why one man's medicine can be another man's poison.
Folic acid deficiency depression types are very intolerant to SSRI's and these patients have been linked to suicide and homicide after taking them. I think it's criminal not to test people for this deficiency before prescribing them anti depressants!
Then there are copper overload patients, over methylated patients and patients suffering from toxic metals or pyrole disorder as their chief problem. These can all cause depression, anxiety, irritability, panic, confusion, delusions even schizophrenia! If you want to get better, they key is to figure out your own biochemical individuality. Find a Dr under The Walsh Institute to help you. They can check your methylation status and check for deficiencies, overloads and disorders. I've decided to spend the extra $ and try for myself. Naturally your health insurance won't cover a lot of it, so be prepared to spend a little bit.
I know there are also tests like 23 and me (the genetic part) which might let you know your methylation status. Whether or not you decide to take medication, I believe it's important to first check your biochemistry.
You can check Dr William Walsh out on YouTube if you're into the science aspect.

Trying to understand the "purpose of depression", why human evolved this "state of mind", assuming that it has a purpose instead of being just an accident like cancer.

I would try to use the social life of wolf as possible explanation. There is only one pair of dominant wolf and all other member of the group, no matter their family relationship, need to submit to the authority. The dominant female make sure to be the only fertile with her urine which interfere with the reproductive cycle of every other female.

If the dominant male or female dies, there will be a power struggle until a new one emerge and forcefully bring back peace in the group. Once the hierarchy is established, every member of the group accept it's purpose in life : find food to help the dominant couple to raise their family.

Even if the submissive members don't spread their genes, they help the specie to survive over long term so their is great incentive to keep in the gene pool that dichotomy between one dominant/many submissive members. The social insects such as ants and bees are extreme examples of that natural selection criteria.

I propose that feeling of depression is an automatic system in our brain to make us less likely to challenge the authority. It is a way to make us give up any hope to progress in life, convinced that trying to fight will fail miserably. It is our way to accept being a subordinate, saving precious energy to both our self and the rest of society.

The purpose in life of depressed people is to survive until, some day, they may become the most experienced member and get the recognition of other member of the group. This can happen if the dominant ones at work are promoted in a different unit or if the company is bought by another and the new direction cleverly identify the most valuable employees.

A pay increase can act as a signal, but more important and subtle changes in the work place are much more likely to transform a depress employee into an happy one.

If the depression is not related to work but to personal life, if you think that nobody will ever love you, then I am not the right guy to help you. Sorry.

I also disagree with the common perception of depression as 'disease' or 'mental illness'. I find depression as a condition that happens naturally to varying degrees in individual people. My depression makes me deeply compassionate and empathetic to people's challenges, pain, suffering. It opens my heart and soul towards humans, animals and nature surrounding me. It makes me grateful.

I wish there'd be something like 'Depression Anonymous', a network within which we can learn and accept depression as being part of us.
It is what it is.
When my winter depression sets in about mid November, my inner colorful perception and outlook on life becomes gray. Mid February, color returns, and regular anti-depressants work again. During the dark months, I long for someone who KNOWS (as opposed to 'knowing about') depression and just listens to me unconditionally. That's all I need; everything else I can handle during the winter months.

I despise having these things because everyone I say about it to just says something consoling, and just changes the subject. I've had several people tell me to get over it, which is literally impossible to do. and people always give me a lecture about how people are "a part of life" and it drives me batsh*t crazy when someone says that because of my social anxiety. I almost get sick and puke if I have to meet someone new, or have to go to somewhere where there is a crowd, I can barely even talk to my friends and family anymore because my anxiety is so bad. I overthink all situations and I get scared that I'm going to screw something up. (spoiler alert, I always end up screwing something up, which in turn makes me even more depressed) my a.d.d and ADHD make everything I do or say confusing to both me, and others, because I either "forget what I'm talking about, change the subject about 3 million times, or go off on a million different tangents. I have the worst memory of anyone I know, and everyone always tells me that I have a good memory, and I hate it. My OCD makes it so I need to have everything in a perfect setup. I have surges of anger randomly in the day, as if my body is going "Why did it have to be this way!? Why was I supposed to have this awful disorder in the first place?" People think 'depressed' is just another word for sadness. Now I have accepted depression. Now I just feel that this is just a part of life. Like I was supposed to have this in my life. And now that I think of it, it's going to stay that way. Forever. I am plagued with depression and it will never be cured. During adolescence, it will be there. During adulthood, it will be there. During seniority, it will be there. During death, it will be there. During the afterlife, IT WILL BE THERE. I am stuck with the worst thing I could imagine, and no-one believes me. It can't be cured, it won't be cured. For eternity. It's hopeless.
Nothing I can or do will help with my god-forsaken curse. I cannot do anything anymore. I am locked in a cell that I have created. I did this. Me. This was all my fault. I am depressed because it was my fate. And to you, reader, I hope it isn't yours. Please have a good life while you still can.

I have always wondered the ratio of biological versus environmental causes of depression.

It seems making someone lose someone they really care about or screwing their life over is a surefire way to make them depressed.

So really, if anyone feels depressed, I'd guess that in the vast majority of cases, the problem stemmed from the person's life situation/outlook and personal philosophy.

If you experience great success in life, you work at your dream job, are surrounded by people you know genuinely like and care about you, and generally experience progress - but you are still depressed, THEN you can probably assume it's a biological reason.

If you defend your depression with a victim mentality then you're never going to get anywhere. That's why I decided to change one of my senior courses at the last minute and take AP psychology instead because you need to understand how the mind works in order to understand yourself and others. This all stemmed from a painful but awakening experience I had this summer.

I used to be one of the smartest kids in all my classes and would often complete tasks with little effort compared to my peers. This lead me to believe that I was "better" than others and this mentality was only reinforced when I started to get a bit popular in my school. I would constantly look down on other people but only in my mind. However, I started smoking weed heavily in high school (at first it was due to curiosity but then I became addicted). By the end of junior year, I had decimated my GPA by smoking everyday and not prioritizing my grades. I started taking harder drugs (in retrospect I realized that I only did it to please other people). During one night in the summer leading into senior year, my friends and I decided to trip acid. A couple hours in, I lost all sense of ego and began thinking about all the bad decisions I made in high school and how it affected my life, my friends and my family. I began having a psychotic meltdown (I didn't know that this is what was happening to me at the time); I lost all sense of self-awareness and I couldn't control what I said or did. My mind was moving at 1000 mph but I had no control over my thoughts whatsoever. I began acting very strangely in front of all my friends- I began making loud noises and weird gestures. The fact that I couldn't comprehend what was happening to me or the fact that all my friends were watching (some of them I knew from childhood) only made it worse. To top it all off, some of my friends began taking videos of me while this was happening and I didn't know until the event was infamous all over social media days later. When I got home, I was in a state of constant paranoia and I couldn't trust anyone, not even my own brother. I began to realize I was depressed (I never thought I'd ever say that since I was ignorant towards the subject my whole life until now) and I developed crippling anxiety that caused me to shut out all my friends for the whole month of August. I didn't respond to anyone who tried to reach out to me and debated deleting all of my social media. I ended up wasting most of my summer even though all of my friends were only trying to help me.

The day after this incident, I threw away all of my paraphernalia. I haven't smoked since that day. I watched self-help videos during the entirety of August. I vowed to do whatever it took to reach my full potential as a student. I've begun practicing meditation and working out 5 days a week. I stopped reinforcing my victim mentality with negative thoughts. I remind myself everyday to keep everything in perspective (so many others have it worse off than you do). I learned true compassion and stopped looking down at people for things they can't control. I sometimes still have negative thoughts (I'm only a week into my senior year and this whole experience is still fresh in my memory), but I'm slowly learning to transform my mind and ultimately my life . My mission is to live a fulfilling life so I can spread happiness and joy to those around me and be a role model for my siblings so that they can be the best version of themselves.

If you're struggling with depression, just remember that it gets better. We are all born with the same mind. Negative emotions stem from negative thoughts. Don't turn to drugs in order to evade the stressful problems in your life as it only makes those problems worse. I recommend reading books to improve your mentality and develop new habits. I realize that my experience may not be as bad as yours, but that shouldn't deter you from living a happy life. No matter who you are or what you've been through, you can always make a change.

I'll tell my story for anyone willing to listen. I'm a 15 year old boy, and I've always been a happy positive person. My dad and sister had bipolar depression and my mom never understood. And neither did I frankly. I was always patient with people, but I never really understood, how can somebody be depressed? I've been sad, but I never understood it. Eventually my dad got sick of my mom, a combination of Zoloft and the way she didn't understand his depression. He left both me and her and i didn't even know where he went. I was pissed, and sad at the same time. I started to have hallucinations. I started to wonder what my life was even worth. Not to mention I had but 3 friends at school, and since I always took their jokes, they continued to always pester me, but I wasn't allowed to say anything back. I'm 6'2, 190 pounds, so it's not like I'm a small guy, I'm physically strong but emotionally weak. Eventually I heard where my dad was living. I was right on the brink of dying, and I knew nobody would ever love me. And then I met a girl. She was beautiful, smart funny. Not the kind of girl who would want to hang out with me. She said she needed someone to talk to, and she told me she had bipolar depression. At the time I was having suicidal thoughts, so of course I knew she needed help. She was always talking about how she wanted to kill herself. I never told her about my suicidal thoughts because I was afraid to tell anyone. I told her how my sister has bipolar, and how she tried to kill herself at work, and is in a mental institution now. The girl told me she would be there for me if I felt this way, but then was like I know you don't have suicidal thoughts. I wanted to tell her so bad. So months passed and I was about done with my life. I knew that hardly anyone cared about me, so I took a dozen sleeping pills, to kill my self. I threw them up, because I was scared, I was too scared to die. I told my one close friend, I'll call him Greg for the comments. Greg laughed when I told him that, and I felt betrayed. And that's when I truly knew nobody loved me. I decided to tell the girl that I was going to kill myself. I texted her and she seemed  shocked! Me the happy kid, with such a positive outlook on life was going to kill myself. I don't exactly fit the emo stereotype of a depressed person. She begged me not to do anything, so I didn't. I missed my dad a lot, he seemed like he loved me, but then he left. But then she thanked me for telling her this, and that she never thought I felt this way, and she was glad I told her. Well eventually I asked her out. A guy like me never deserved a girl like her. And then I met another friend. He was a nice, nerdy boy. We became new best friends, and I was in a great relationship with my gf too. Well he told me that he had depression. So I let him meet my girlfriend so they could be friends. Well they sure became friends. And apparently they were hanging out behind my back. Like, excuse me you wouldn't even know each other without me. Well one day my girlfriend told me that she was in love with my friend. And then she left me for him, and they are living a happy life. In a way I should feel glad, I made them happy. This made me very suicidal again, so I texted a suicide hotline. The person on their didn't seem to care at all what I was saying, and they terminated the text before I was even done. So here I am, listening to this song, just trying to keep myself alive. Anyone else got a story? I'm glad to listen

It may sound corny, but God loves you and knows every single thought and what you are going through as well. He will never abandon you. Jesus knows your heart and even understands that sometimes negative ideas or thoughts, are just like a physical illness. Stop being so hard on yourself, do not ever feel ashamed to seek for help from an individual, whether it be friend, parent, counselor, pastor, teacher, or whoever. The truth is, alot of people feel exactly the same way you do, but are living with it all hidden trying to pretend it is not there. Do not fall for negative thoughts, this is part of the lack of serotonin in the brain, it is not real. For instance, if you have doubts that someone may not love you, remind yourself that the reason your mind is thinking this way is probably due to a chemical inbalance, and don't take it at face value. No matter what, where, or who you are, it is never too late to live a happy life, and things WILL get better, even if it seems bleak at the moment. You may not see the hope right now, but that is again a negative thought due to a chemical inbalance, and most likely, if you talked to someone about what you are going through, they might even open up a dialogue themself so that maybe you can help them, and in turn, help each other. Every life matters, and you are special and loved by your Creator, and He will guide you if you put your faith in Him! Put your trust in Him,  cast all your cares upon Him, He will carry you through the toughest battles, and NEVER will forsake you.

The few people who do notice usually think it's just one of those days for me, but in all honesty, I'm falling apart inside. I'm nice to everyone because I know how cruel and accepting the world can be. My mom always tells me to "think more positive"....It's hard to do that when you've felt like a pathetic failure your whole life with little to no reassurance that you'll be (at very least) ok. I've struggled for about 7 years now, and the only thing that keeps me here is telling myself that I need to be here for my friends who can be suicidal. Because if I left the world when I wanted to, 3 of my friends would be gone too. Luckily, we're all still here and seem to be doing alright for the moment. My only hope is that we can all overcome this disease and learn to love ourselves enough to say "I'm ok" and genuinely mean it.
I send my best wishes to all of you out there struggling and hope things look up. Lots of love to you guys.

Trapped.
I am trapped.
I float in darkness.
Waiting for someone, something.
Waiting.
Hands reach out to me.
So close yet so far.
Some of them are closer now.
But I know - those hands are evil. They laugh at me.
I call for help, but my cries cannot escape my bubble of depression.
I sink, in a downward spiral, an endless cycle.
I close my eyes. Wallowing in self-pity. It's oddly comforting.

Then it happens.
I stop sinking. I look up.
There it is. A faint light.
A light at the end of the tunnel.
It beckons to me. I know that the light is disguised as hope.
I rise.
Slowly but surely.
The journey is tough.
The journey is painfully slow.
But I can get there.
I will get there.

My elder sibling subjected me to emotional abuse that I endured for years. The constant harassment and malevolence still fresh in my mind. He has since moved away, but I still remember. I want to forgive him, but I cannot forgive myself. I have no right to quarrel with God, and It is not good to quarrel with people. So the anguish is unfathomable, that I shoulder the pain of these memories myself. And so, in the back of my mind, I am shackled, not only with my sibling's incessant insults, but I still hear them as though I am the one speaking them.

This was not something I had to deal with on occasion. This was not a bully at school robbing me of lunch money, or tying my own shoelaces together. This was someone of my own blood. I had to live with him for twenty years before he moved away. And I've had to suffer in the knowledge every single day, that he hated me. I do hope that light can be shined upon sibling abuse. The issue is just as, if not more cruel to the human spirit.

I've been back and forth with depression for three years now and actually right around this time two years ago I had gone to my first therapist. I've had good days, I've had bad days, and I've defiantly had much worse days. I have been suicidal before, twice actually. But even though I'm not suicidal anymore, I still have really bad days where I just don't want to get up I the morning, where I don't want to eat, where I don't want to talk to anyone.


I lost a lot of my innocence at a very young age which is how I developed depression at only 12 years old. I'm only 14. And there's a guy who I had dated (I know it's really young to date but I was young and stupid, it's part of the story just go with it) and he manipulated me, made me feel safe then would do a 180 and just make me feel like shit. But because I was so young, I kept falling for his "safe act" over and over again because I didn't know what to do and after a while I felt trapped because I eventually figured out that he was playing with me and I just didn't know what to do anymore. When this guy found out I was depressed and cutting (this was 7th grade, when it started and we weren't dating at the time) he gave me advise on how to cut,  how to hide it. I thought that was it. Nope. He found out  was suicidal and gave me advise on how to kill myself. From his advise, I've attempted suicide 8 times.

As I said before, I'm not suicidal anymore, I've over come that part of my life nd I can control it a bit more, if that makes any sense??? Not gonna lie, there were a few times where certain situations pushed me over the edge, I wasn't suicidal but I sure did end up cutting a lot and I don't know if anyone else out there with depression has ever felt like this  but I was legitimately alone because I knew I needed help, I knew I needed to stop cutting but I felt like I would just end up back at another therapist and  my experience with therapists aren't the greatest so I forced myself to get through it myself. I had cut so much that my body like lived for that adrenaline of being cut, kinda like your body craves nicotine when you smoke? I guess I was, or at least my body was, addicted to cutting in a sense? So when I forced myself to stop cutting I started having a lot of panic attacks to the point where I could barely breathe because I wanted to cut so bad. And what made it worse is that I told my boyfriend (at the time) everything about my cutting issue and that my body was kinda craving it again and he ended up breaking up with me while I was having one of those kinda panic attacks where I was coughing and barely breathing (my parents weren't home at the time or they were sleeping, I can't remember) and when he broke up with me, I was at such a venerable point and I was so fragile, I guess, that I completely los tit and stopped fighting and (I was in the kitchen) I just stood up form my seat and just pulled out one of our sharpest knives and cut. Not a whole bunch but only a couple times. I of course cleaned the knife and my arm and bandaged my arm and I just went to my room and cried.

But, even though there's a LOT more I didn't share with all of you, you know I haven't had the best time the past few years and it sucks that I'm only 14. Y'know, I'm suppose to be this kid in high school having fun with my friends, playing soccer, going  plays, cheering on my friends at their games and such. I mean, I'm going into 10th grade in the fall! But even though I'm not that child that loves the world and is happy 24/7, my depression doesn't hold me back, not anymore. That's why this year is going to be different. Yes I will still have those bad days and maybe a few of those worse days but they won't last forever. And now that I've over come that "cutting addiction" Twice actually, and the fact I did it by my self? I feel that's amazing and that even though I have 42 (maybe 43 idk) scars from cutting, and even though I can remember every moment that caused those scars, it just gives me a reason to keep fighting and I want to be a therapist when I grow up so I can help others get through what I've been though, or possibly even worse than what I've been though.

Pleas, if you've read this far, first thank you for reading I know this was long, and secondly, if you're dealing with depression, anxiety, anything, really. Know that things get better. That may not mean shit to you or it'll mean the world to you, I don't know. I know I didn't believe it wen people said It'll get better so I don't blame you. But I'm 14 and obviously you've read through a few of the worst things that have happened since I became depressed. But just look at me! I'm okay. I'm not great, I'm not fantastic, but I'm okay and I can say I'm okay and mean it for once. So please, if you're still reading, I hope you realize that even though I have no idea what your situation is or what you're going through, if you just keep fighting and hold on even when things look or seem horrible, you can get through them. You can do this. Just because I don't know you, doesn't mean I don't believe in you. I believe in you. You can do this. You can fight this. You can be okay. Just hold on. I promise. It will be better. Always Keep Fighting <3

I feel so peaced off when I hear about "depression". This term is just so stupid.
And that's why some journalists come up with some articles like "how to overcome depression".

It's not possible to gather all the different kinds of suffering, and describing it as "depression".

Some people face depression because they lost their girflriends, their husbands or get fired.

That's purely psychological.

But there is another type of suffering, which is the result of an objective situation, leading to objective suffering.

For example, it refers to people getting accidents, such as having their faces burnt in a fire which scarred for life.
This situation will result in objective future suffering..(physically but most and foremost socially, getting rejected daily).

So STOP TALKING ABOUT CURING DEPRESSION, IT PEACES ME OFF!!

It's not smart to rely on some teen girls saying like "yeah, I overcame it so everybody can, you just have to embrace life" seeing that the girl has objectively no "real" issues.

Some people lived objective situations, which changed them physically or mentally (like bipolar disorder) which objectively destroyed their existence.

The study of depression should be developped to another level, if it wants to relate with some people.

I hate being depressed, mainly because I have no reason to be! My life is great! I'm doing well in college, I have lots of friends, and there's nothing particulary bad going on at home. I guess the worst thing that's going on is that I'm transgender, but because of how shit my depression is, the fact that I'm transgender is completely insignificant to me right now!

When people are depressed, they're usually triggered by something massively horrific, but then I'm just a complete mess for no reason. I refused to get medication for so long because I'm terrified of it, but it's got to the point where I've nearly attempted suicide on three different occasions in the past few days, so I agreed to take them anyway.

Even my psychiatrist is surprised at how distraught I am at ABSOLUTELY NOTHING. I feel like I'm here being a wreck at nothing whatsoever, and then there's kids in Africa who are probably more stable than me emotionally! It makes me feel like a cunt when I'm having a full-on mental breakdown, but I have absolutely no reason to be having one.

Anyways, my hippocampus is probably the size of a small orange pip now, and I have two exams in the next month, so we'll see how they go for me with my new tablets in my system.

Thanks for reading this massively long post of me complaining about how great my life is!

Its more about numbness. Usually feeling as though you're a wretched individual. Defective to the core. You view everything through a dark veil thats over your eyes. You're numb to human  emotions which are the cornerstone of one's well-being. Excitement, joy, happiness - these are not things you get to experience. But you do get to experience nasty emotions( such as guilt, shame, anger...) which stab your psyche.  Days are obstacles meant to be overcome. These obstacles are usually overcome by an addiction. Or by anything you can find which allows you to escape life and the gnawing emptiness that you feel. You distract yourself from reality.

I really wish that more people knew about depression (and other mental illnesses) as much as we know about the physical pains like cancers, broken bones,  and heart diseases. It seems that in society we just focus on the outside or external problems and never truly address the internal issues, or if we do, it's very "hush hush." I'm grateful that you made this video and that you are helping to expose depression. I'm tired of the lines "get over it" and other disrespectful comments only due to ignorance. It's time that we grow up as a species and really care about our casual question "how are you" and help each other out and understand each other. It's the only way that we will grow.

It sounds really strange, but sometimes to cope, I'll listen to an episode or two of Welcome To Night Vale. People think the themes of not being important and your actions having no long term effects are bad, but they have the opposite effect on me. Being reminded that my existence, and by that nature all human existence, is microscopic in the grand scheme, it makes me feel better. As if to remind myself that no matter what happens today, tomorrow will come regardless. Earth could be destroyed, but the universe would not halt its processes just because humans aren't there to witness it. It just makes the world seem smaller and reminds me that bad things will pass no matter how long it takes.

There's something about me I don't fully understand. I've felt the clear effects of depression, but I seek no help. I worry and fear to tell the truth. I don't want to deal with therapy, or pharmaceutical drugs to make me feel 'better' or 'happy'. I go around and tell the people that mean much to me that I have depression. Since I have never been inclined to seek this 'help', I wander my home and hope to endure it the best I can. I can't say that I officially have depression, because I was never officially 'diagnosed' with it. I don't need a diagnosis. I know I have it. I just don't seek the help. I talk with close ones to cope with it, but it seems they slowly lack the interest in helping me anymore, and it really makes me question myself. Even with this corruption of mind, I still like to try and comfort others when they are sad, even expressing honest compassion and happiness to cheer them up. In a way, I sacrifice and give all the happiness I have within me to make others happy in return, leaving me a husk. But in the end, I'm seen as 'noble' for that. I'm not noble, I just have a heart out for those who have to suffer and endeavor such pains that I feel day by day. Back to the first sentence I typed, I don't understand this. I don't seek help, yet I can find joys in helping to free others of this pain, only to return to the pain once the deed is done. I've lost all of my IRL friends, and I have never spoke to them since Senior year of High School, and I'm 20. The internet is my 'last hope' for any source of joy. I can cope with this pain of mine, but it creeps on me at any time of day, and I grow tired of it. No, I will not kill myself, nor have I attempted it... only thought. This rant has gone on far enough. To those who suffer this insidious torment, I wish you all happy times, I really do. Just don't let it control or ruin you, you're all special in the best of ways. And you, reader. If you've read this far, thank you for reading this... it means a lot to me, and that I'm not just some unnoticed paragraph among millions of other words.

Lol. All these kids thinking they have depression.

Depression is not circumstantial. You are not depressed. You are sad because of stress and school. Just accept that and be grateful that you do not know what depression is.

Depression is a deeply-rooted feeling, much deeper than what you feel going to school.

Sadness is not depression. I used to think I was depressed, but never really understood depression until after I had a brain injury. I was raised by an abusive family, but I wasn't depressed, like I had thought. I was extremely sad, all the time, because of my circumstances. Once I escaped those circumstances, I became happier.

Depression cannot be cured by circumstances of any kind. It is a train of thought that embodies hopelessness and can only be cured by coming to terms with the dilemma within.

You teenagers? You're not depressed. Most of you, anyway. And that's a good thing. If you're not depressed, don't go trying to understand it. Experience is understanding, and none of you need to feel depressed, for absolutely any reason. Let me try and explain this better, although it is impossible to understand unless you experience it. I used to believe people could choose to be happy, in all circumstances. I was right and wrong. Happiness can be had while depressed. Joy can be had while depressed.

Many of the people replying here are not really depressed, as far as I can tell. Even if they say they've been "diagnosed." The way they describe it, I just don't believe it. They are missing the core concept. Like these people who claim to not understand what happiness is. I am happy every day, but I am still depressed. Let me try and explain it to people who think they're depressed, but are really just experiencing long-term circumstantial sadness.

Depression is not euphoria at all. And sadness is not depression. I used to think I was depressed, but never really understood depression until after I had a brain injury. I was raised by an abusive family, but I wasn't depressed, like I had thought. I was extremely sad, all the time, because of my circumstances. Once I escaped those circumstances, I became happier.

Depression cannot be cured by circumstances of any kind. It is a train of thought that embodies hopelessness and can only be cured by coming to terms with the dilemma within. Mine happens to be an existential crisis.

If you think you'll get better if something happens, you're just sad. There is a difference, but you cannot truly understand it until you experience it. But that's alright. There is absolutely no superiority in being depressed, and nothing good can come of it.

Depression is hard to really explain to people who have never been depressed. Depression is not just sadness. I was never depressed before my brain injury, even if at certain times in my life, I was so sad that I thought I was depressed. I didn't understand what depression is.

You'll know for certain when you're truly depressed, because you realize nothing external can make you happy long-term. A new-found love, friends, family, nothing will cure depression. This is because depression is purely internal. I became depressed, truly depressed, after an injury to my brain, but the thought that really made me become depressed is the uncertainty of life itself. An existential crisis, so to speak.

You'll know when you are depressed when absolutely nothing makes you happy long-term, and although your mood changes day-to-day, your outlook on life remains dismal. I still love hanging out with friends and doing fun things. These things make me happy short-term, making nobody think you are a depressed person. But they can never cure depression, because that can only be cured from within.

The only thing that can cure my depression is deciding to ignore my existential crisis and accept that nobody really knows why we exist, and that the only thing I can do is enjoy life to the fullest extent possible, ignoring philosophical conundrums. No matter how long I ponder my existence, my question will never be answered until I die. Because of this, there is absolutely no reason to continue thinking about it. I'm going to die eventually, no matter my course through life.

I feel really empty. I'm not happy, or sad, or angry. I feel hollow. I can't sleep, I don't eat, and all of the things I used to love doing seem boring. I don't care about anyone, or anything. I don't care when my friends say they aren't my friends anymore, and I don't feel happy when they are.

A very personal, scary message I posted on my Facebook:

Dear Friends and Family,
This week has been an extremely difficult week for me on top of a very stressful, emotional year. Heck let’s just say it has been a very stressful, emotional and difficult life thus far..
I suffer from many things like depression, anxiety, ocd, insecurities and a desperate need to find a purpose in life that will consume me and revive me and bring back all the positive emotions I have not truly felt since I was 12 years old.
It has gotten so bad that this past week I almost quit my job; packed up all my things, and was was about to head out and leave everything I know behind.
This may come as a shock to a lot of people. Is this the same cheerful mailman we see walking around town never without smile on his face? The same guy that is friendly and outgoing to every person he has the pleasure of bumping into? The same kid the posts goofy FB statuses about cookies and Netflix and nothing ever all that deep or meaningful?
You have seen what I have chosen to show you.
I chose to never show any of my weaknesses publicly and privately because of my ego.
I wanted people to believe that I am a successful, happy go lucky 21 year old mailman living the American Dream. The majority of this has been a lie.
We live in an age fueled by deceit. My generation (including myself) post pictures on social media of happy selfies, group photos living it up at college, and cool events we are attending. But what you don’t see is a broke college student crying on the phone to their mom 5 times a day. You don’t see the hours and hours of hard work put in and the stress of which can really take a toll on a person's physical and emotional well being. This is just one example of many people who are muddling through their lives but you would never know it. Nobody likes to show weakness. It’s awkward and it’s ugly and easier to hide and ignore than to share.
But judging by all the self-deprecating memes and dark humor posts that are shared around social media so many people feel this way.
And with tools like social media that could be used to reach out, connect, relate, help, heal, and understand people across the word (which was not available but 20 years ago) instead we choose to use it for vanity and ego and hide important parts of ourselves.
With all that being said, I have decided to do something kind of scary.
I have changed my instagram account to @RealMaxMartin.
Starting today the lies end.
I will be using this account to share my personal feelings, struggles, battles, and anything else I feel could be beneficial if someone like minded could see and walk away even the tiniest bit comforted and understood.
I will start slow with small issues and gradually delve deeper into who I am -as to not overwhelm anybody or myself, but the goal will be to post at least once a day.
Not all of it will be pretty. It will be awkward and ugly and uncomfortable and you may think “why would he share this for everyone to see?”
At this point I do not care.
So many people including myself are struggling.
And we only sink deeper when seeing other people succeeding thinking “why is it so hard for me?” “why can’t I be like that” “what am I doing wrong” “is no one else feeling this way?” “what’s wrong with me?” “will i ever be okay?”
Little do we realize so much of what we “see” is so far from the whole truth.
So if you would like to embark on this adventure with me please go follow @RealMaxMartin on instagram. But if at any point this account depresses you please unfollow because that is not my intent. And feel free to share these words with anyone you think could benefit from them. Let's heal together <3

Honestly,
Max Martin

Okay so I'm studying psychology at the moment and we have just started to cover depression and this video got me wondering about the correlation between deadlines, stress, depression and the ability to retain information. Say there is an exam that you have to study for and you are becoming increasingly stressed about it, based on what this video stated, stress can cause the Hippocampus to reduce, thus reducing memory recall efficency. The inability to recall information correctly could then further increase stress and so the spiral continues and before long the effect of what has happened could potentially reduce you into a state of depression. So my question is this: If you were to use a safe amount of these serotonin increasers, on both healthy and depressed individuals, would it allow your hippocampus to maintain/improve its state and thus allow more efficient recall of information. I'm very intrigued to know if somebody can help answer my question.

p.s. Just for the record I'm not suggesting that anti-depressants are to be used as a study aid, I'm merely curious as to the effect that they could have.

There's sound but all I hear is empty noise. I see words but they just seem like endless thoughts that I can't process. I listen again. I re-read the lines over and over and over. But nothing registers. Silence when there's supposed to be something. Nothingness. I can't make sense of it. I can't make myself care when there's nothing to care about. I'm going delusional. My mind keeps me occupied in an endless loop of repetition with no purpose. I'm doing something right now but I don't know what. There's no thought in it. I've become automatic. No sense of self, feeling, meaning, purpose. All of that is gone, stripped away, I don't even know if it was ever there in the first place. I'm physically present but a million miles away. Just going through the steps that feel comfortable, safe. Repeating them. Again and again. But I'm not there when the pen drops and I pick it up. I pick it up and it drops again. Lines bluer. Smear. Loud sound drains on and into an incessant buzzing. I'm left standing straight in the path of the arrow as everyone moves around always busy, moving, doing something. But I don't know what it is that they're doing because I'm busy doing something too, I just don't know what, because it feels like I'm doing nothing. Nothing makes sense when all you know is nothingness. So I still do the same things that I've always done. But it feels empty. Meaningless. Stupid. I guess I'm feeling something if life 'feels' stupid. I just can't define my emotions clearly in my head. So it feels like I don't feel anything at all. Maybe I'm automatically going through the motions because all that is that's left of me is a giant gloom of emotion too large to define, to do anything more than LET things happen to me, especially when life keeps going on and on with no reason. I don't move because I can't. The arrow could hit my heart but it wouldn't register. I don't even feel pain anymore. I'll just stand there, straight in the path, thoughts & feelings too jumbled to think about moving or care about feeling more pain. Was I supposed to do something else? Maybe there wasn't anything ever there in the first place. I've gone automatic. I need some help, I think. But maybe I wasn't even thinking that. I just thought I thought that in this endless stream of endless thoughts that I can't seem to process. Is this depression?
