I am depressed, I have been depressed for the longest time, and it all started because of my brother, all of the sudden he started calling me names, made fun of me and called me ugly, but when I try to fight him, he leaves me bruised and bloodied on the floor crying. My parents will do nothing about it because they only see the good side of my brother, and say that it was my fault, not my brothers. And then for the past year my whole life turned upside down. I started school and all my friends were not in my class so I was left alone. And it seems when you're sad, that's when all the kids start teasing you. The only good side to the past year was my elderly cat. She was sweet and stayed by my side when I came home, all my best memories with her was at the end of each day, when everyone in my family was asleep, me and my cat would sit beside each other, in my room, while I read. This is where I got my love for books. As I suffered through the year, summer was finally 3 days away. I was really happy and excited to be able to finally get away from the kids at school, and when I came home My elderly cat greeted me. I was cheerful that day and I put my necklace I was wearing around my cats neck, It was a stream of fabric that held a star charm that changed colors as it was moved around. I left my cat with the necklace once I was done petting her and went into my room not realizing that would be the last time I would ever see her again. I was on my bed, with my laptop, when my dad came in my room, and gave me the worst news of my life. Someone ran over, and killed my cat. At first I thought it was a joke, I mean who would kill my Sushka? But I soon found out that it was not a joke, my beloved cat was with the stars. I stood there, watering the ground with my tears as my family digged a hole in the forest next to the lake, and put the box that held my Sushka (Sushka was my cat's name) into the ground. When I came back home from Sushkas funeral, I never knew such grief. The last few days of school were absolute torture. I lost the will to stand up to my teasing classmates and I was pushed around, insults being thrown at me left and right as my classmates took advantage of my grief. My mother then realized that the necklace Sushka was wearing was mine and gave it back to me. That necklace is very dear to me. I wanted to wear it all the time but as I learned through my life, I can't be trusted with jewelry or i'll somehow break it. So I have kept it in a small box next to my bed. Now I am in 6th grade, my summer is over and I have already experienced the first day of school. It was terrible and I don't want to experience another day, so I skipped school on the second day, which is today. My brother found out I missed school and contacted both my parents ignoring my pleading to stop and not tell them. Now I am counting down the seconds until my wicked mother thinks of a punishment for me. I haven't shared my depression story with anyone and it feels good to get it of my chest before my mother takes away my electronics for who knows how long. Sigh

The genetic predisposition and difference in the way people with depression experience things (remember something slightly wrong or associate it with certain emotions) is interesting. But I believe this video takes away that depression and other mood disorders are all about how people react and deal with things - if bad things happen you will probably feel bad about it - the proper term is resilience, meaning how well you deal with things and a range of things can improve or remove this ability. It is worth noting that the use of chemicals (drugs/medications) can be a double edged sword when dealing with depression and anxiety, and should only be used as a last resort and with other therapies under regular monitoring from a professional to prevent dependence.

Another interesting point is that serotonin is not the only neurotransmitter involved; I myself was diagnosed with clinical depression and anxiety nearly 10 years ago and doctors keep trying to prescribe me SSRIs and tricyclics (types of medications for depression), however I have found that when I am at my worst (uncontrollable crying, palpitations, muscle tension, ect.) very dark chocolate eases my symptoms massively and doesn't come with the scary insert of prescribed depression medications - if anyone else wants to try it out, speak to your doctor before stopping any medications as they can have some nasty withdrawal effects, also I use chocolate that is at least 75% cocoa, anything less doesn't have the same effect and higher fat and sugar content can cause other health issues. Chocolate makes you feel good as it contains a chemical that mimics dopamine - another neurotransmitter - suggesting that serotonin alone is not the issue.

I have my own theory on probable trigger for depression.

I have studied online suicide rate on things like wikipedia, and what we see is that places with high ab blood types, like japan and korea, also have high rates of suicide even for their economic prosperity and mental support, other places we see high suicide rates are in eastern europe, also with very high ab populations, here in canada where i live, inuit people have the highest rates of suicide, and also the highest ab populations, on top of economic issues.

When you compare and mentaly graph areas of their propsperity and estimated mental health support, it appears the areas with the largest amounts of ab populations, have the highest rates of suicide.

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1928200/ here in this article in the click to view pages is the ONLY article i found on blood type and depression, and we see very high rates of ab patients for depressive cluster disorders.

And here http://www.m.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/news/20140910/study-rare-blood-type-may-slightly-raise-dementia-risk we see scientific evidence of a raised risk for dementia in ab patients, and we know dementia and depression are related as they have to do with similar portions of the brain.

My theory is not that ab blood is the absolute cause of depression, but that the blood type may cause a sensitivity to major depression that can be irritated by environmental factors.

The sensitivity may also not be due to the blood type, but a distinct set of ancestors who handed down the genes, as well as the blood type, which may cause the sensitivity, and this may have major implications in genetics as relating to depression for screening of sensitivity and suicide prevention in the future.

For imformation on suicide rates and blood type, wikipedia "blood type by country" and "suicide rates by country" and compare.

You´d think that in modern times the human race would be able to provide a solution for almost every disease, look at all the progress in fields other than mental health. We know that this is a very complex condition that can vary greatly in every affected person, but it´s still very hard to believe that there aren´t better options out there. There ARE many options, but most of them turn out to be useless in many cases, the severe cases.
In my case, 7 years ago everything went out of control, and since then, nothing was even remotely like it was before the outbreak of this horrible disease. An eating disorder, anxiety and perceptual problems evolved over time, everything I see is blurred, instead of a tree, for example, I see a tree and its shifted contours, so it seems like there´s the same tree again in another one.
Got put on antidepressants, antipsychotics, was in a mental hospital, went to several doctors, nothing helped. Might sound familiar to quite a few people out there. After many years you start to realize that the world with its treatment options cannot (or doesn´t want to) help you, so you´re left with two options: keep on living a life in agony while over the years the symptoms become worse and still doing the best you can, trying to look after yourself (healthy eating, exercise, positive thinking, expressing yourself through art etc., all the stuff they tell you might be helpful), but all those things can be, once a certain severe stage is reached, only a little bit helpful, if anything.
Suffer long enough and you´ll start to think that this is never going to change, at the same time you feel: something that feels SO MUCH abnormal must have a specific cause. Still alive after 7 years (although it doesn´t feel anywhere near like being alive), you´re left with guesswork, reading about biochemistry and brain chemistry. You order supplements, in search of THE REAL CAUSE. Is this merely unrealistic wishful thinking? Maybe, but what can you do if no one but yourself does anything to improve your miserable existence. People say it so often that it sounds like a cliché: The only one who can help yourself is you. Many of us would be dead already if we´d have solely relied on doctors, and when it comes down to it, you´re left alone with something no one should be ever left alone with, helplessly left to your cruel fate.
Still, we are unbelievably strong and suffer, despite everyone around us being able to really live instead of JUST SURVIVING.
Respect to all of you who hang in there, I know what it´s like, every day we stay on this earth is a huge personal accomplishment, an accomplishment that only you and fellow sufferers can see, whereas the vast majority of people will never know what it´s like and how hard it can get. We are fighters, everyday, and until we find a solution to all of this (or something that makes life a bit more endurable, many of us would be grateful for every small step), we have to keep on doing what we were forced to learn, what we do best after all this time: fighting.

I was bullied when I was 13 and I developed obsessive compulsive disorder when I was 13, I lost all my friends when I was 16 and was diagnosed with severe depression, generalized anxiety disorder, health anxiety and social anxiety disorder, I also became an alcoholic and became addicted to a lot of different types of drugs, when I was 19 I had a nervous breakdown, and in January and February of this year I had two more nervous breakdowns (I'm 21 now), I've been having suicidal thoughts every single day for the last 4 months, and I've just recently talked to a psychiatrist who has given me some medication which I'm going to start taking tonight and I'm seeing a therapist next week.. I gave up all the drugs I was taking in February, but became an alcoholic again in March, and I've been drinking heavily ever since, but I'm about to drink my last beer, because I need to quit for my health and because I hate the embarrassment caused by going into a shop on a Monday morning to buy beer and also because on the medication box it says not to drink alcohol when taking the pills.. I hope the pills/therapy help me and I'm going to start exercising every day and eating a lot of fruit and watching motivational videos in the hope that it helps me get better, I'm also starting to socialise a bit now, and hopefully I can get some new friends.. The last 8 years have been really terrible for me, I've just been trying to cope as opposed to enjoying my life.... The only good thing which has come from all this is all the art I've created.. But I don't think that makes up for all the suffering I have experienced.... But anyway, I just felt the need to say what I've been through.. I sincerely hope that I'm able to get better and start enjoying life and doing cool things like perhaps trying to become a successful artist soon, even though my chances of success are very small, but yeah, I have nothing to lose, and potentially everything to gain.. so starting today I'm going to make every effort possible to improve the quality of my life, and if I fail and nothing improves, and I just continue to suffer for every second of every minute of every hour of every day of every week of every month of every year, then I guess its time to give up.... I hope I get better.

I just want to point out to everybody with depression that it sucks (I'm going through it too, 3rd year of 'extremely severe clinical depression and less severe anxiety), BUT at some point you need to confront yourself, tell yourself that you're better than this, and REMEMBER:

90% of the world are objectively living a worse life than you and I. The fact that you're able to watch this video is proof enough.
It's a hard pill to swallow, but it really makes no sense why you would hate such a statement when the only reason you'd hate it is because you'd want to keep telling yourself your life is horrible (and why do you want to? Does it just make you feel more sympathetic to your cause? Wouldn't it make you happier to believe your life is pretty good?) I used to pity myself, hell, I still do sometimes, but I think about people who are tortured for 11 out of their 12 waking hours, and thinking that my life is great in comparison to billions of people instead of 'my life sucks, all my rich friends living in the top 1% of most livable and advanced countries have better lives' makes me feel worthwhile instead of meaningless garbage.

Depression isn't a mentally solved issue most of the time, it's usually a chemical one (in the brain) but IT IS possible to stop sad thoughts. Just understand that what you're going through is something a person as strong as you can deal with even if you're living in such a great society that it's hard to accept that.

People think that being depressed means you can't be happy. Well thats not true. I still have days when I am really happy and I am able to laugh. In reality, depression is a back and forth between feeling way too much or feeling nothing at all. In depression, the overwhelming emotion is sadness and feeling worthless/ not seeing the point in anything. But there are many days when it is impossible to feel any emotions at all.
So no, the cure to depression isn't simply to make that person happy. A real cure would be finding a way to help depressed people find purpose in feeling and in living out their lives, and just generally helping them to feel something.

Idk about you, depression triggers in me when there's some unsurmountable obstacle(s) that happened recently or built up over time. I think depression really is only a transition between realizing something we want and also our lack of capability to attain it due to lack of skill, willpower, confidence, whatever. and so its like running towards your future only to realize midway that you are a very long way off, you are tiring and losing energy, and the ground below you is crumbling. and so your mind goes into a state of confusion a mix of fight or flight reactions, of losing hope, of survival and preservation, of statistics badly in your favor and without a clear cut solution, your mind melts due to the overwhelming stress leaving you paralyzed and disassociated with a hint of fear. and so I think the best way to deal with depression is to actually tackle the problem but a very Very small part of it. forget what might or could happen, just focus on the now and immediate. focus on achieving the next baby step. like if you can shower or eat and sleep on schedule, that would be commendable as those are actions that rebuilds your life and confidence. then break your problem down to very simple tasks and do those. don't worry about the end or how small your actions matter, just focus on doing because by doing what you can, where you are, with what you have, right here and now, you become in control of your life in this very moment, and he power to affect now is really all there ever was. everything else is in the past or imaginary.

I'd just like to point out that the feeling of depression is one that you can only really understand if you've had it.
Too many people seem to think it's a constant feeling of "sadness". It's not. You can feel sad and having depression worsens the symptoms but it's not the overriding feeling. Depression is a feeling of nothingness and that's a very difficult concept for people to grasp. When I explained this to my friend he essentially refused to believe me and said I was wrong because apparently it's not possible to feel like that. It is. Imagine doing things that you usually find fun or enjoyable and not even registering a single thought or emotion. The suicide attempt argument about people feeling sad is debatable but for me I think it's more wanting to escape a constant nothingness.

So depression is a mental illness, not just a feeling, that is caused by some factors? Can people living a normal life  develope depression for no reason? Or must there be factors causing it?

I do think the label "disease" for depression isn't really the best. I'm not saying it's good to be depressed, but I think the cause of depression is usually based off reason, and that anyone can get it. I think the best way to cure depression is to understand what caused it outside the brain. Example: If I was depressed, one reason could be because everyone treated me like crap at a job. If that stopped happening, I would no longer be depressed.
Though other reasons could be something from inside your body (e.g. Cancer) too.

So of course you can't "get over it" snap like that, but I don't know if taking medicine will solve the main core of what caused it. If all the reasons were solved, the core would be destroyed.

Depression is when you feel unmotivated to the point where you can't even visualize your future because your present actions contradict your views, but at the same time, you have legit reasons to support your present actions. It's like a no-way-out situation wherein you feel like at some point you will hurt yourself from making yourself feel better. For the most part, your hobbies, interests, and relationships get affected by it, and so your life becomes so boring, and the cycle continues. Thank God I am not a suicidal person. I just need some counselling and a way to end the cycle. :)

PSA: If you are prescribed SSRIs, look up the Activation Syndrome and have yourself monitored and observed by people close to you for 3-6 weeks after the first pill. In a nutshell, that is when you are most vulnerable to suicidal ideations and, if you're like me, could be very close to successfully committing them during this window. Personally (and I did my thesis on the hippocampus on SSRIs, but was never able to fully confirm this hypothesis), I think it depends on how small, or "damaged," the hippocampus is and how much "re-wiring" is needed of it in order for the SSRIs to work. I've heard and read cases where some people's thoughts were too much, while it didn't even affect them at all.

For me, the urge to self-terminate during this Activation Syndrome felt as natural as guzzling water when I'm thirsty, if that helps anyone understand the symptoms.

SSRIs are not a quick fix; you have to be patient with them.

I believe that aside from getting professional help and possibly medication, there are two main things you need to focus on to feel fulfilled and to help you rise out of depression or overcome anxiety. It may not be the same for everyone, but focusing on the following two things has really helped me:

You have to know, not think, but know; that you are able to have a positive impact on the world. You need to create or work on something that could either help or inspire other people. Never underestimate the influence that a kind or productive action can have as any inspiration or help you can provide has a ripple effect. This ripple effect is that anyone who knows about the work you are doing will feel encouraged to help a cause that they feel passionately about. Some examples could range from simply helping fix a fence in someone's garden, or volunteering at a homeless shelter, creating inspirational music or videos, or going on a volunteer trip abroad to do some relief work.

The second thing is to venture into new places that provide new experiences. The world is vast and is filled with staggeringly beautiful landscapes and cities, and I believe a natural high is experienced when exploring them. I believe that another main cause of
depression is when life becomes too familiar, and the same routine is experienced for too long. Venturing into the unknown and unfamiliar enables you to have more vibrant experiences and makes it easier to enjoy the present moment, as you are appreciating and absorbing what you see around you. It will also give you greater confidence in your
ability to organize and take care of yourself. You can start off by simply getting the bus or the train to somewhere near your local town that you've never been to before, exploring the area, perhaps taking a few photos, and then travelling back home again. If you do want to travel abroad, the best way to start is to gather as much information as you can about different and affordable ways to travel, make a plan, and then go for it.

In my view depression is caused by your genetics, your past experiences, accepting thoughts as fact when they may not be true and acting on these negative assumptions. I believe that getting an expensive car, or house or having a high paying job will only make you happy temporarily, as these are material things that although provide you with security, will not provide you with long lasting fulfillment.

On a side note, there is a user called Vagabondsteve who has uploaded lots of videos where he gives advice, and while I don't agree with everything he says, most of the videos have been an extraordinary help to me, so I would strongly recommend trying out his channel.

Making the purpose of your life to help or inspire people in need in anyway you can, whilst exploring all the beauty the world has to offer, is in my view a very fulfilling way to live.

Depression definitely seems to have an evolutionary paradox. Researches show that half of the population in the planet experience major depression at least one time in their life. But the brain plays crucial roles in promoting survival and reproduction, so the pressures of evolution should have left our brains resistant to such high rates of malfunction. Mental disorders should generally be rare why isn’t depression?
This paradox could be resolved if depression were a problem of growing old. The functioning of all body systems and organs, including the brain, tends to deteriorate with age. This is not a satisfactory explanation for depression, however, as people are most likely to experience their first phases of depression in adolescence and young adulthood. I have always known depression to be a lack of serotonin due to the genetic strain, as it was described. It makes sense that serotonin helps with neurogenesis in the hippocampus because it is responsible for the brain cells that regulate mood, sexual desire, appetite, sleep, memory and learning, temperature regulation, and some social behavior.  After finding the function of serotonin it is easy to understand why researchers thought it was a serotonin deficiency that causes depression.  However like the video stated, there are many other contributing factors as to why someone may have depression.  It could be the environment they live in or work in, it could be an event that had just occurred that triggered it, it could be a genetic predisposition to it, or it could be a combination of all three.  At any rate, I think therapy should always start with prescribing someone serotonin drugs.  This will begin neurogenesis and start the client back on the right track to a healthy brain.

This is very interesting!  I know many people who suffer from depression and I have always wondered what exactly is going on in their bodies.  I thought that is was an imbalance in the brain, but it is so much more than that.  The hippocampus, which controls emotion and memory, becomes smaller during depression.  Studies have shown that people who have a shorter serotonin transporter gene are more likely to become depressed.  There is so much more to depression than just an "imbalance in the brain".

One thing I have noticed is the effect of certain medications on depression and/or bipolar, particularly anticonvulsants and other psychotropic medications. I am epileptic and have bipolar disorder (which runs in my family) and I have found that when taking one type of seizure meds, my lows increase massively to the point where it's almost constant with very few manic episodes. While I agree we don't have perfect control over our mood, just because it's biological doesn't mean you can't do anything about it.

In fact saying it's biological is saying nothing.  It's tautological, because everything about thought is biological.  It has to be. Where else would thoughts happen besides the brain?  Biology does not completely negate choice.  There are biological differences when people are told to think about happy or sad things, or when people deliberately meditate, so our choices influence our biology.  A rather famous study showed that becoming a taxi driver in London creates the biological effect of new neurons in the hippocampus in order to handle it.  London Taxi Drivers are required to complete "the Knowledge" test to be licensed. 

What is it about "the Knowledge" that grows new neurons in the hippocampus and could understanding that help people with depression?  We should have even more studies to look at ways everyday human behaviors and choices influence mood and brain biology, but then those aren't quite lucrative for pharmaceutical companies. 

I agree people shouldn't be dicks to depressed people and shouldn't tell them to just "suck it up".  That's mean, but disempowering them by suggesting there is nothing they can do in their everyday lives to influence their moods for the good isn't doing them any favors either.

Here's my Depression story...I've developed depression from long term chronic pain, & now also have anxiety & panic attacks. This may not be based off any studies, but take my word. Once you hit a certain point in depression, there's no going back. You can maybe feel okay again at some point, but a full recovery is impossible. I've hit this point, and I know that no medication or professional will ever get me back to the happy self I once was.

The only reason I'm alive right now and haven't killed myself is because I've learned to distract myself.. And I've gotten good at it, but I'll always be miserable and suicide will always often be on my mind.

My point is, don't be like me. If you have real, legitimate depression, treat it. It doesn't get better with time, it gets worse. I wish I could've told my past self that, but I can't.

I became depressed after my grandmother passed away two years ago. When she died, I just saw all of the negative sides to life... More people began to bully me, and I considered suicide at one point or another. Since April, I've been trying to become more positive... It's not completely gone, but I'm getting there. I would've been "cured" sooner if I'd told someone about how I feel... I regret that now. If you're someone with depression, talk to someone about it...holding it in will actually make it worse; I've learned that the hard way. Just hold on. Theres people who would miss you to death. Sometimes literally to death. Even though I might be a stranger, I would miss you.. And so would so many other great people that care about you.

I have social anxiety and depression. It all stemmed from elementary school. I always used to get good grades and would ace my tests. Later on in the year, I was classified as a gifted student which is similar to AP courses in high school. But because of this, i had a lot more pressure to be perfect. Teachers often expect even more of me, almost always perfect. I never thought that the gifted program was for me. I just felt that i wasn't as smart as they thought I was. All this pressure made a giant impact on my life. Because I was young, I just thought that this was normal, even though it caused a lot of stress. I started to be very harsh with myself. In everything. Grades, looks, personality; I didn't have to be better than everyone, just up to my own standards. I was always a little shy, but this made it ten times worse. Just getting a question wrong in class would stick with me for the entire month. Sometimes even the entire school year. I could never stop thinking about it. I didn't like presentations, answering the door/phone, or even asking an employee for help at the supermarket. When ever i saw in myself in the mirror, I hated it. Not just the appearance, but my personality. I was afraid of failure. In my head I knew that at the end of the day, other's people's opinions didn't matter, but I couldn't stop caring about it. So one day, I decided to tell my mom. she was supportive, but she didn't quite understand. She said "maybe it's just a phase" and to be honest I really wanted to believe it too. So I did. I ignored it for a while, and thought that everything was okay. But one day in class, they were taking a class photo. The teacher asked me to come over but I said no. I really hated pictures of myself because I hated myself. The teacher then said, "C'mon, don't be 'that person''. I don't know what it was, but all my thoughts came rushing to my head. 'That person'? I'm SORRY that i hate myself and that I am afraid of failure, and that I don't know what to do about it. While I was thinking this, I suddenly burst out crying. The fact that I started crying made it even worse. I was so embarrassed. My friend who I talked to about my situation, took me outside to calm down. when I came back inside, the teacher asked me if there was anything that he needed to know. I simply said "No" and out my head down on the desk. I wanted to go home home and forget bout everything. I did forgive him because he didn't mean it like that and he didn't know about my anxiety. That comment still stayed with me for the rest of the year though. The only thing i found peace in was video games and anime. They made me feel like I could do anything. They were my escape from reality. The only thing I was missing was a friend. Someone I could tell everything to. I'm kind of a loner and because i was afraid, I convinced myself that I was better alone. But now I realize that  need someone. That was this year, in grade 7 and next year I will be in Grade 8 and moving to a new school. I am really anxious about going because I don't think I will make any friends, but maybe I can finally get a fresh start.

I have a good tip for dealing with depression

Do NOT to to reddit for help

It's full of trolls

Here i will copy and paste a troll post from there as an example:

"You ever have a little sibling that won't stop pestering you no matter how hard you try to get him/her to stop? No matter how hard you yell, cry or stomp around, he/she is just going to keep bothering you. He'll bother you when you do your homework, when you are trying to relax, when you're trying to have fun, whatever. The only way for this kid to stop pestering you is to stop letting him/her pester you. Because all and all, he or she is still your little brother/sister, and you love him/her (deep down).
You have depression. This is a part of your life that you must accept, like the annoying little brother/sister, instead of fight. The more you learn to be patient with yourself and your emotions, the easier it will be to cope. The fact of the matter is that depression is something that happens to you- and it probably will for a long time! Depression, no matter how fucking terrible it is, makes you, you. And you're pretty cool, so that's important.
So don't fight it. Don't shove it away. Don't hide it. The more the stuff it down, the harder it will fight to come back up. Accept it, feel your feelings, and (as goofy as this is going to sound, this is the most important part of what I'm going to say) love yourself for doing so. Because you're you, and you're never going to be anyone else but you, so you may as well learn to love even the bad parts of yourself. Embrace your sadness like a child who is scared, not like a evil monster who you're trying to kill.
This all takes practice. DEFINITELY. But it helped me a lot. If today is still pretty bad, have a depression party! Watch sad movies and paint black pictures and listen to sad music.
Please feel free to PM me if you need to talk. I hope I helped a little bit."

READ THIS: Meds only treat the SYMPTOMS, there's a reason psychiatric medicine has only improved in terms of having less side effects rather than having better efficacy in terms of anti-depressants: because they are looking in the WRONG PLACE. Here's a dirty little secret: there's no such thing as a "chemical imbalance" in the brain, simply because there's no such thing as a "chemically balanced" brain in terms of neurotransmitters. 

This is a problem in the MIND, so treat the cause not the symptoms or you will be battling this monster for the rest of your life!

I'm constantly self-aware of everything that I do, always forcing myself to act a certain way around others. The second something feels exciting to me it instantly goes away. You know what I hate about depression? People never understand. Depression can be a completely subjective matter because of how creative and thoughtful we can be. For me, I started feeling depressed for no reason. I'm not talking about "having a bad day", I mean grieving like someone just died (I have no experience of someone dying and I wish I never do, with exceptions of Jimmy Saville, Josef Fritzl and people like them). I used to have mental breakdowns at night (for me, they were just thinking about what made me depressed to the point it overwhelmed me and I cried), but then I started doing it for the buzz (yes, believe it or not but mentally breaking down at night makes you feel better the day after, at least it did for me, it's a good way to vent your feelings but don't do it for too long otherwise the elation the next day will start to gradually shorten until it's ineffective, in fact: Don't try it at all, it may be healthier than cutting but it's a bad addiction). But at the time I really didn't have a reason, just grieving on a daily basis for no reason. So, what did I do? One of the worst things ever (not cutting, I may be depressed but I have never deliberately cut myself unless there is a good enough reason like extortion). I remembered this conversation that my severely (he really fucking was!) friend had with another friend. He said "None of this might not even be real, it could all be a dream." Now you're probably thinking, "How does that make someone depressed?". Well, my mind basically needed something to blame, and here it was. It instantly latched onto the memory, expanding it out, all the sadistic and immoral possibilities filling my head. It was horrible. I set myself up with the worst possible reason to be depressed. I was against morality. I thought it was the religion that nobody thought about. The fact that it isn't real, look around you, what do you see? Walls, radiators, sofas, tables, warmth, love. It all implies meaning, but we have none. I couldn't help but think that genesis was an accident, the big bang was probably a mistake. Everything is so meaningless, it doesn't matter anymore. People keep saying how religion and science were complete opposites, but morality was the real deal. How do we live meaningful lives whist we have science screaming in our faces how much of a mistake we are and how we'll be lost and forgotten when dead? Why do we live knowing this, this futile journey that might now even be real, everything you're experiencing could be a dream or just plain non-existence? But this wasn't the only thing, life and death scared my too. Death. A process where everything gets erased and you become non-existent, once again meaningless. How does it feel to not be able to feel? No touch. No smell. No sight. No sound. No taste. To think that without these senses, we wouldn't actually be what we defined as "being alive". But don't get me wrong, I have completely moral problems too, I have no self confidence, I know I'm unattractive bla bla bla. I don't care about this, it's a bee sting compared to my lack of morality. However, I thankfully have a bunch of proper lads at physics, I practically said the same thing as I've just noted here to them and they listen, and they offer solutions that I can relate to, but most likely won't work. However, my parents instantly told me to "Stop thinking about it". The worst possible thing they could say to me, it shows that they didn't understand. I never felt more alone in my life since the start of Year 10. Anyway, this was after my friend convinced me to tell my parents and see a counselor/psychotherapist (PLEASE DO IF YOU THINK YOU SUFFER FROM A MENTAL ILLNESS LIKE DEPRESSION, BIPOLAR & ESPECIALLY SCHIZOPHRENIA). 

Take care lads and ladies, if you have any questions please ask. I hope my story vindicates how subjectivity increases the difficulty of solving depression.

EDIT: One session my counselor asked a VERY important question. Did I want to actually stop my depression? I still said yes, because I wanted to feel happy whilst being able to think about the same stuff for days (may be weeks, months, years and more) on end. Another important thing about depression: It's not whether you feel happy or not, it's your ability to feel happy. I can't, I just grieve during my downs periods, and if I'm not grieving then I'm empty or annoyed or embarrassed or guilty or anything but happiness.

I personally feel that depression is influenced primarily by external factors within the environment. When those factors prove to be impossible to change, depressive symptoms emerge and are exacerbated upon continuous exposure to those factors. However, if those factors or circumstances change for the better, the depressed mood will instantly improve. But some people have the tendency to seek out aspects of their lives that cannot be changed and their depression only worsens.

Everyone gets depressed. It's not natural to feel happy go lucky all day every day. Depression is the body and brain's way of recovering from prolonged stress and tension. The extent to which depressed mood lasts varies from person to person depending on both internal and external factors. It's really the way you respond to the depressed mood that predicts how long it will last. If you let it pass without reacting intensely then you will notice that it will abate.

Depression is not solely based on Serotonin!!! It's just a by-product of the condition. SSRI drugs have been shown to be slightly more effective than placebos. It cannot account for the whole story. Those drugs wreak havoc on your body and are not effective in the long-run. Doctors keep prescribing them because of the insurance companies. The best treatments for depression are exercise, social interaction, and most importantly time. Maintain a healthy diet as well!

I would consider myself a normal happy guy, and I battle with mild depression pretty frequently. It's the highs and lows of life. It's normal to feel pretty blue every once in a while. I would say the main source of depression obviously is being unhappy with your life, not being where you want to be. Bad relationships, bad job, overweight etc are all causes. And the great thing is people can change those things so they can become happier, but the problem is the vast majority of people give themselves permission to do nothing to improve their life, and make up a bullshit sob story they tell themselves to justify their inaction. They settle for less and don't chase their dreams and goals. They think it's too hard and just quit. That's the problem today, people just quit. An overweight depressed person tells themselves "I was born this way" and this is their story to justify them not exercising at all and not eating properly. We do enable a lot of "depressed" people to bullshit themselves into accepting their sadness. Stand up like a man and fix your life, I think you'll find your sadness will fade as you take action. You have to participate in your own rescue. Coach Corey Wayne is a great lifestyle coach I highly recommend him.

Depression. Most of you, who never had suffered under it won't understand what it does, but more importantly, how it feels.

Let me explain it to you, so that you'll understand it.

Think of a daemon (=depression) housing inside you. That daemon is controlling your thoughts, and the way you handle things.
The daemon wants you to do bad things, you can call it "self-destruction-mode", until you're dead, or winning the fight.

You feel bad, the daemon feels good then.
Because of that self-destruction you lose your friends, which will make you feel worse, which in fact will make the daemon feel better and stronger, and you do other stuff, which are bad for you, until, you're killing yourself.
So it is a spiral, and it is really hard to get out.
Most of the people don't understand it, they tell you, "get up!" "go outside and enjoy the weather!"
I mean, you would, but the thing is, you can't. And that's the point.
Most of us know,when we are tired, we don't want to go making sport, you have no motivation.
And that is the way most depressed people feel, about LIFE!

So the feelings?
It is pain. Not a physical pain, but a mental pain. Think of the most important person in your life.
Think of that person dying infront of you, in your arms.
That is the way we feel ALL THE TIME!
Until some point, you just don't want to feel that anymore.

Depression is a desease, in which the one who suffers from it, get's controlled from it.

These childish cartoon illustrations are laughable testaments to the personas of individuals who believe "depression" is accurately definable as an unequivocal disease process in all cases. Two abstract concepts such as the natures of disease and misery could never exist together as "depression" in perfect harmony with the reality of the transient world. Yet fools who hold themselves to be gods, misguided in their dogmatic persistence of a perfect scientific truth, believe they hold the authority to lay such a tyrannical judgment on such a wide variety of idiosyncratic miseries through the utilization of a facile explanation.  In reality, all individuals with a diagnosis of depression hold fundamentally different transient mindsets of themselves, their respective spiritualities, and the surrounding world. Since the common belief is that this "disease" supposedly bears a location within the mind, my logical conclusion must be that "depression" is only a subjective concept and not an external truth, as such a vague phenomenon could not be expletive for such variety, just as a higher discrete being is not responsible for all floods, earthquakes, and hurricanes.
     Superficial objective fact gods such as AsapSCIENCE are in part held with such credence due to a misinformed and isolated American public that runs away from the world into the internet-verse of instant gratification. Despite a commonplace societal acceptance of this internet channel as entirely truthful, the second-hand pharmaceutical agenda-driven platform purported in this video seeks to obscure the truth. The agenda should be obvious as the video-producers never acknowledge the existence of contradictory studies to these many theories of "depression." Additionally, although the opinion presented in this video is that "depression" is treatable with "antidepressants," several meta-analytic studies produced by Irving Kirsch demonstrate that all psychiatric drugs, including "antidepressants," used in treating "depression" perform little better than placebo in reducing subjective aspects of "depression," and furthermore demonstrate the slim disparity between active drugs and placebo is due to an enhanced placebo effect.
     The congregation of masses into cult followings has been ubiquitous throughout the ages. However, with only the recent establishment of the technological Western Sphere, no such cult phenomenon compares in scope to the psychiatric industry's enslavement of so many innocent minds.

I suggest another video on depression. This time explaining what happens when one has this illness, which gender, age group, profession, etc. exhibit this most often. And which regions have most people with depression. I heard USA has a lot of people taking anti-depressants regularly. Where I'm from, we are more concerned with occasional flu passing through town, and no one shows any concerns about this depression thing.

For future reference please do not use the phrase " a depressed person". Rather, say "a person with depression". The focus should be on the person not the illness. When the focus is on the illness you push aside the person which is dehumanizing. While I know the main point of the video is depression it is not something that can be covered by a simple four minute video.

Additionally, I feel as if this video was put together simply for likes and views. The execution was poor and it seemed like something put together by a random tumblr user who looked on Wikipedia for information in order to slap together a short video. While some might say, "Something is better than nothing." which I agree to some point, the video should have been longer and more informational. Also, some might counter by saying, "He has extra links in the description." Great, but I guarantee that almost no one is going to click on them. As a person who has suffered through depression for many years I am perplexed and disappointed by this video.

I love your video's, but must say I do not agree with this one. The information in you video is clearly biased toward a north American view on psychiatry. In the old world, scientists have a bigger focus on psychological en societal causes for depression and more so for a holistic view that takes in to account biology, social en psychological aspects of the problem. Anyway there are already some problems with calling depression a disease, since there is no clear view on what depression actually is, what it looks like, what the onset is, what the cause is, how it develops and how it is cured. We pretty much have non whatsoever rational motive to call it a disease. Enough emotional and economic reasons though. It being a billion dollar industry and there are real people suffering from this problem. And calling it a disease with a focus on biological causes is definitely not without consequences... It is way better viewed as a broad syndrome where different people have different symptoms in a different way, but al clustering in the same broader syndrome. Depression is not a single disease entity, there will never be found a single cause and the will never be a single 'one size fits all' cure. This is because depression is tied to experience and is ultimately always a personal story. And so it is obvious what happens to these people and there story's when we start calling it a disease with a biological cause.

And then one more thing on the brain study's... Please read this book and do a video on it. It would be great! Bainwashed, The Seductive Appeal Of Mindless Neuroscience from Satel and Lilienfeld

I'll break it down for everyone. He starts by saying, with over 350 million people affected worldwide, its obviously a real and serious issue. Then he asks but what exactly is depression? is it biological? So he states that it's real, then asks if it is. The question is whether it's a literal disease, and whether that 350 million means anything.

He carries this weird circular reasoning throughout. "When we look at the brain of a depressed person..." He should say when we look at the brain of a person 'diagnosed' with depression. The whole point of the video is to see if it is something that can be diagnosed. i.e. a disease. He continues: "The longer a person has been depressed..." again.. aren't we determining what depression is?? He does same thing when he mentions the study about twins and bipolar 'disorder.'

His conclusion is that depression is a disease with a biological basis. Yeah, it's biological in that you cannot have a mind without a brain. That's his retarded reasoning. To the same extent, me being happy, confused, angry, etc. has a biological basis, as does playing an instrument or washing the dishes. What he means to conclude is simply that sadness requires having a brain. He never even defines what a disease is......

A disease is a physical disorder of the body. It is also "a particular quality, habit, or disposition regarded as adversely affecting a person or group of people." Under the second definition, the first is taken metaphorically. e.g. "The article cites intolerance as one of the most dangerous of society's diseases" "He sees crime as a disease that too often plagues the poor and disadvantaged."

Depression is not a 'real' (literal) disease. That's why it's a MENTAL illness, and not a brain disease. A sick mind is like a sick economy. It's a metaphor. Up until the 70's, homosexuality was a mental illness, and before that, masturbation. The video is stupid and wrong and misinforms dumb people who then feel empowered by their ignorance. If the last comment upset you then it's talking about you.

I will say this, I was diagnosed with stage 4 cancer at a young age, at the time my Oncologist said I had 6 months.  I would be lying if I said I was not Depressed at first, the fear of death, the anguish, the unknown. Anyone that receives that kind of diagnoses knows what I'm talking about.  This is going to sound cliché but its the truth.   You are not alone, I don't care who you are there is always someone in your life that cares about you. Even if there really is not someone. Then there is still people out there with a worse situation than yours, meaning they are facing the same hardship you are. Find that person, if they wrote a book, read it. Find that encouragement. Your attitude is everything, if you think you are not going to be healed well guess what, your body will respond in kind. I'm not saying its a magical cure but studies show a connection between positive attitudes and survival rates especially with cancer. Depression is real, but I don't believe that it can be treated with a pill. We need to treat it at the source not just mask the symptoms. These things are true for anyone but this last part is for people of faith, God is the only way to reach true everlasting peace facing any trial.  Anyway I for one am grateful to be here today, its been 18 months since my diagnosis and I am feeling good. As someone who has battled chronic depression, I can say that it's very hard to describe how a depressed person feels. I became very anxious and then depressed 7 years ago, and it felt like a dark cloud descending over me that trapped me in like a tiny, claustrophobic snowglobe. I'm pretty sure that my depression was brought on by anxieties due to external circumstances at the time, and that due to my genetics I was more prone to getting generalized anxiety and depression. I also have compulsive anger issues that have plagued me my whole life, so I wonder if that may be a part of the whole equation.

My greatest fear during that time was that this depression would never end- that I'd be stuck feeling like this for the rest of my life. Luckily, though, that turned out not to be the case. I took anti-depressants that slowly started to help a little bit, but my pattern of anxious negative thoughts continued (like concerns about world events and feeling guilt/responsibility/fear), and the major feelings of depression continued. I decided to repeat to myself over and over again that my misery wouldn't help anything in the world get any better, so what's the point. It wasn't an overnight cure. It took a long time of actively arguing against my negative thought patterns in my head, not allowing them to keep swirling around unchallenged. I'd say that now I'm pretty much cured of depression.

I did try slowly ramping off my meds a couple years ago, though, and that was NOT a good idea. All the old anxiety and depression came back, but added new symptoms like stomach pains and heartburn. I did feel like I was weak for "depending on meds" to be "normal", so that's why I tried to ramp off them. I still want to one day try ramping off the meds, but for now, as long as I take the meds, I can function and live a fairly normal life.

I can't believe some people still don't believe clinical depression isn't real.

Yes, some people are overly-dramatic and just need to "cheer up" or work on "finding the joy in life." This video isn't about those people. It's about people who have a real physical, chemical, genetic, mental disorder. And you can't "just get over" a disorder.

You can't just tell a schizophrenic to "just will yourself back into sanity."
You can't tell a person with Alzheimers to "don't forget."
You can't tell a person with chronic fatigue or narcolepsy to "just wake up."
You can't tell a person with clinical depression to "stop being sad."

All of these have to do with REAL chemicals and deformities in the brain.
Trying your best to "just get over" something is a nice concept.
But it doesn't work like that.﻿

Thank you for bringing an informative science video regarding depression!  I suffered severe depression several years ago, overcoming it with a combination of lifestyle changes, medications, and counseling (it can become a lifelong battle for some, which is scary to think about).  

Most people don't understand how serious depression can be, and think it can be solved by simply exercising or being with friends more often.  With depression, your own brain fights against you, and can make you think, even if you are surrounded by loving family and friends, that you are really alone, and that life isn't worth living.

If you are constantly having thoughts of physically harming yourself, or you suspect a loved one might be (it is EXTREMELY difficult to tell, which makes it that much more tragic), PLEASE, seek help, either from your doctor or a trained counselor.  Living with depression is difficult, but not impossible.  Suicide is a just permanent solution to a temporary problem.

Depression is a constant battle for me. It goes away but then eventually comes back. I find little joy in things I once adored, and sometimes I just want to lay in bed and do absolutely nothing. It sucks not being able to keep a real smile on my face, I can make myself happy when drawing and hanging out with friends but after the happiness only lasts so long until I'm once again back into my depression state. Oh well, I suppose this is just the way I was meant to live :/

Most of the time, for me, it's less emotional and more physical. Too much commotion, too often, and I am just...drained. I loose my ability to focus on or care about what people are saying or what is going on. My head and body just checks-out. I need my down time. Like a phone with a faulty battery. Takes forever to charge. And, the charge doesn't last long in practice (even though it should at least be 1:1 in theory). 6-8 hours sleep, a meal, a good hour or two to get ready to interact. That purchases about 30-45 minutes of being alert, active, and outgoing in the world.

See, here's the problem with saying that depression is always real and we should never tell anyone to get over it:

Meet Jane.

Jane is a teenage girl in a suburban town. She lives in a moderately nice home, and has no real reason to be sad about life.

But Jane is sad because her dad won't let her go out tonight. He's just looking out for her, but Jane is an immature little shit.

Jane screams at her dad. Jane tells her dad he's a fucking asshole. Jane tells him she's depressed.

Jane's dad knows she isn't depressed; she's just an immature little shit.

But Jane is so mad. Jane starts acting depressed. Jane starts listening to depressing music and brooding in her room. Jane starts convincing herself that she actually is depressed.

But Jane still isn't depressed; she's just an immature little shit.

Jane finds out that depression is a "real thing" and she starts shoving that in her dads face. Telling him that HE'S THE REASON she's depressed. HE'S THE REASON she cuts herself and listens to depressing music.

But Jane doesn't cut herself because she's clinically depressed; Jane cuts herself because she's an immature little shit.

Where's Jane today?

Well (assuming Jane didn't kill herself to prove a point or something)...

Jane lives in her parent's basement at the age of 25. She still has yet to do anything with her life, and she cycles through scumbag boyfriend after scumbag boyfriend (who also does nothing with his life). She basically takes advantage of the world around her using the excuse "I'm depressed; you can't just tell me to get over it."

Jane has become an immature big shit. All because no one ever told her to get the fuck over it.

THE SCIENCE OF DEPRESSION

What exactly is going on inside of a depressed person? We look at the scientific basis for depression, and shed light on the fact that it is a disease with biological, psychological, and social implications.

We can see it in our biology, in our genes and in our actions. For those who are depressed, it’s not simply something they can ‘get over’ and ‘be more positive about’. ATTENTION UK VIEWERS:

If you are looking to get help for depression, I have some recent experience in trying to do so. From my experience, going to a GP was NOT very helpful; they gave me some very vague recommendations about possible treatments, and I didn't get any in-depth analysis of my mood, why I might be feeling down, etc. The treatment they did recommend was a little bit more helpful, but again I felt like they weren't really focusing much on my individual needs, perhaps because they (rightly) concluded that I wasn't suicidal and therefore not a priority.

DON'T be disheartened and give up if this happens to you! I would personally recommend doing some research online about specialists in your area, such as Mental Health Services, and contacting them directly; its still covered under the NHS, and hopefully they'd know more about how to help you out. :)

There seems to be a lot of discussion and debate over both the role of exercise and some form of meditation in the treatment of depression. It is well documented that exercise stimulates an increased production of various endorphins in the body, which are themselves often related to improved mood. What remains to be seen is whether or not the act of exercise itself (not the effects) plays a major role in effective treatment. The "average man" is a rare thing indeed, in fact it is more common for us to be different from one another in most ways than it is for random members of the population to share many similar characteristics. So the act of exercise itself may affect different people in different ways. Some will respond positively to exercise (many feel as though it helps occupy their mind elsewhere, it gives many a sense of reborn purpose, some enjoy the social and interactive aspects) while others may not feel benefits in the same way (while it may make one "fitter" the increased stress on the body can increase any anxiety already felt, or perhaps an individual ends up putting too much pressure on themselves to "achieve" which only serves to worsen their mood if they fail to meet expectations).
As for meditation, once again, we will all respond in varying ways. Often meditation is included in activities such as yoga and other eastern sports/activities. Much of the purpose of these activities is to "be kind to yourself." The thoughts associated with depression vary from person to person, but many people may feel as though they aren't good enough or they feel as though they shouldn't be what they are (this is by no means an exhaustive list of the thoughts of the depressed, please don't bite my head off!). These activities, focussed mindfulness and respectfullness, often have the idea of self appreciation and inner harmony as one of their core mantras. Not to mention thr promotion of healthy relaxation and reflection, which reduce the stress on an individual among other benefits.
Just remember you intrepid YouTube commentors, be kind. The idea of the average man is just that, an idea. The norm is uniqueness. Just remember that one person's treatment should not be taken as a "one size fits all cure" and also that what many consider to be pseudoscience is effective for another. Depression is a serious illness just like cancer. It dominates the sufferer's life and, in some sad cases, destroys it. Just as with cancer treatment there is no "one size fits all" treatment. Depression affects the sufferers, those that care for them and that they care for and can destroy lives. While there may be no known cure, we can all help in it's prevention. Living with acceptance could be the start. Just remember, you don't know what's going on behind a facade. Be kind.

Bullshit. We might not have a strong say in it, but we DO have a say in it. We can help ourselves recover, and similarly, we can keep ourselves from recovering. If we didn't have a say, if our mindset and thoughts didn't affect it, such a thing as a depression hotline wouldn't affect it.

...just do want to say, though. Medication can also still help, and it alone can likely help more than mindset alone. I just wanted to point out that we aren't powerless to give up and think that we have no say in whether we stay depressed or not. Or even get depressed in the first place, really.

There is no biological basis for depression/bipolar disorder. It may be biological but you cannot get a blood test for example to see if you're depressed, in fact the only reason it is considered plausible is because so many people characterize themselves as depressed.

And even that has significant flaws in logic since the actual diagnosis and definition of mental disorders has become much more broad and there are many more 'disorders' being added in the DSM.

The thing is, when you push out a cure one of the ways you know it's a cure is because less people end up having that illness, however the more SSRI's and anti-depression drugs are prescribed the more people are diagnosed with depression.

Realistically, 'depression' has no evidence/basis and we cannot know if it even exists and even if it does, the medical industry isn't helping.

I do believe the biological and psychological go hand in hand. For instance, if I want to feel happy, I try to find something that makes me happy, like sports. However, let's say I play in a game, and I have a bad game. Playing a bad game I may not control, because it's just simply my body's inability to perform at a level I want it to perform at. I might have a bad game because I didn't sleep well the night before, I didn't eat enough before the game, I went through a breakup, etc. However, I can still either allow that bad game to dictate my mood, such as feeling sad or angry because of my performance, or I can shrug it off my bad game and appreciate the camaraderie and fellowship that I had with the people that I played with. However, if I invested so much emotion into sports, or into a relationship, and it doesn't turn out well, it would be extremely hard to not become depressed. Just like if a loved one dies, my emotion takes control, and I allow it to take control, because my body wants me to take control.

I think the issue we have here in our modern society is that we put so much emotional emphasis on too many things. In point: we invest too much emotion on things that we cannot control. We worry so much about winning or losing the game, when we really don't have that much control over winning. Sure, the better our performance, the more likely we're going to win, but there's no simple guarantee of that, and just because I want a relationship to work out so badly, the other person may not want to, or, quite simply, may not have the ability to.

I think it's a matter of perspective. There's always too perspectives, but because of our "flight or fight" reaction to things, if we sense great emotional turmoil by a certain event to happen, we will do our best to prevent it from happening. However, this "fight or flight" was only suppose to be used in emergency situations, but now we have this response almost every day of our lives. In many ways, it's drawing our emotion thin, therefore, making it harder to "find joy" in everyday things, or, it might do the opposite, where we're so focused on "finding joy" that once we receive it, we love it, but then have an emotional crash once that joy leaves.

In a straight up comparison: I believe we get emotional highs or emotional rushes like a sugar rush or a drug high. When we make ourselves emotionally high too much, our biology adapts to this rush, or this high, and begins to get use to it, thus, making it "normal". However, because now that the "high" is normal, the normal feels "depressed". It's the same for someone who is so high all the time, that feeling sober feels weird to them, and for someone who is so "high on life" all the time, feeling normal feels weird to them. And just like someone who's going through withdraw from a drug, many people who have gone a long time without this "high" might become depressed for weeks, or even months, without end, because their biology is craving that high that it adapted to.

I feel like we, as a society, allow ourselves to get "too high" off of emotion. We can have 100 things go well for us, but as soon as one wrong thing goes against us, we flip out. We cry for weeks over a relationship that we might forget about in 10 years. We cheer about our team winning the championship that 99% of the will forget in 10 years (or simply might not care in the first place). If you don't believe me (without researching), name the NFL, MLB, NBA, and NHL champions from 10 years ago (2003-2004 seasons). Few may be able to do it, some will get at least one or two right... others will just simply guess, because they simply can't remember.

We either live in the past, or live in the future. Most of us don't live in the now. We don't think about the now. We think about how the now will affect our future. We even think how the past will affect our future (fate). We just simply don't live in the now, and explore the now, and relish in the now. I think by doing that, we are able to get a little bit better handle of our emotions and our mood swings. We may not be able to control what emotion we have, but we can decide whether or not it's an appropriate time for that emotion to control us. It's just simply asking the question of "should I be feeling this way, or not?" and / or "where is this feeling coming from?".I believe we should understand the psychological part of ourselves, almost even more so than the biological, because if we know our biology is going to react a certain way when we put ourselves in a certain situation that will be negative, then it would be best for us, and for the people around us, to try and not put ourselves in that situation, much like how an alcoholic might not want to live alone next to a liquor store or a bar.

We've got to understand ourselves in just the biological way. There are many other psychological and metaphysical factors that play a part in depression, and in order to do the subject justice, we've got to explore all elements (although I understand that this is a "science" channel and talking about the science of depression, but I'm tired of people saying "it's just chemical imbalances that people can't help". I beg to differ, because there have been many cases of people overcoming depression, just like how people overcome cancer. Yes, medical help may be needed, but the psychological, and the metaphysical, also needs to be addressed and corrected if there is any hope of them to be "in remission" from depression. It doesn't mean it goes away permanently if all of a sudden they no longer feel "depressed", but they're no longer feeling the effects of depression anymore, and their biology has adapted to "normalcy". That's what I think we need to try and do. Help people get us to feeling "normal".

I've been depressed most of my life. As a teen I approached my parents about getting help and was essentially told counseling/psychiatry wouldn't solve my problems. I almost killed myself multiple times and they are sooooo lucky that my desire to live was just an eensy bit stronger than the urge to die.

Now I am grown up and have learned some coping skills. I take an ssri and practice mindfulness, good nutrition, regular physical activity, get plenty of rest, and meditate with relaxing music. I also keep myself busy with hobbies and human interactions and a regular schedule to keep things in life running smoothly even when I am on autopilot.

However, the depression is ALWAYS there in the background waiting for my guard to go down. Sometimes it seems to come in my sleep and I wake up sad and have to force the daily routine and increase my helpful coping skills. Sometimes even when I am not feeling depressed I feel hopeless because I know it will never go away completely. I still have suicidal thoughts sometimes, usually when very stressed. The above helps me cope.

On the other hand, I also live a healthier lifestyle than many non depressed people because I have to be aware of how my behavior can influence my mood. Silver linings and all.

While developing drugs and other biological answers to depression is a worthy cause, I think we are focusing too much on it. Medication only goes so far if the individual isn't motivated to get better.
